En su tienda de víveres comercializa todos los productos referentes a la canasta familiar; café, leche, huevos, vegetales, carnes, enlatados, salsas, aderezos, bebidas, frutas y productos de aseo personal como detergentes, jabones, shampoo, sus principales clientes son los vecinos del barrio y transeúntes del sector quienes cancelan sus compras de contado y también les ofrece facilidad de pago. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará un enfriador exhibidor para conservar refrigerados los productos lácteos, bebidas y embutidos.  Ornis considera que esta inversión beneficiará a su negocio porque los clientes observarán mejor exhibidos estos productos que son de fácil rotación y uno de los principales de la canasta familiar.  Ornis tiene metas a futuro las cuales son comprar una casa y tener su propio local.
texts.en:
Ornis is an entrepreneur who is 36 years old and lives in a neighborhood in the municipality of Barranquilla. In 2012 he started his own grocery store after  having worked for many years as an assistant at the same type of store.  While there, he learned all the skills necessary for purchasing products and he became so familiar with this business that he decided to start his own store. 

In his grocery store he sells such staple items as coffee, milk, eggs, vegetables, meats, canned goods, sauces, dressings, drinks, fruit, and cleaning products such as detergents, soaps, and shampoo. His main customers are people from the neighborhood and people passing by. They pay in cash and he also offers credit. 

He is currently applying to Kiva for his first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. He will use the money to buy a refrigerated display case to keep his dairy products, drinks, and meats cold. Ornis thinks that this investment will benefit his business because his customers will be better able to see these products which sell quickly and comprise the basic food basket. 

Ornis dreams of one day buying a house and owning the shop where he has his store.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerated display case to keep his dairy products, drinks, and meats cold.

loans.name: Onesmus

texts.en:
Onesmus is 21 years. He is married and together with his spouse, they have been blessed with three children who are 3, 2 and 1 year old.

Onesmus is a mechanic as well as retail trader; these are businesses he has done for the last three years, earning a monthly income of Kshs. 45,000.

Onesmus has requested his second loan with VisionFund Kenya of Kshs. 20,000, which he will use to buy more stock of retail goods like sugar, maize flour, cooking oil and cereals to sell.

With the anticipated profits, Onesmus will be able to repay his loan as well as provide for his family's basic needs.

His hope and dream for the future is to own a public service vehicle.

loans.use: to buy a stock of retail goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy rice, palm oil, and beans to cook.

loans.name: Twunguke Group

texts.fr:
Dieudonné  fait partie du groupe  Twunguke et  habite à  Bujumbura. Il a 34 ans et est marié à Adelaïde, une cultivatrice. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants âgés de 10 à 14 ans, dont  3 étudient.
 
Il fait le commerce de  pains   depuis  8 ans. 

Il est  à son deuxième  crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il obtient, il  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  beaucoup de pains  à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, il voudrait  devenir un importateur d’habits, et voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Dieudonné is part of the Twunguke group and lives in Bujumbura. He is 34 and married to Adelaïde, a farmer. Together they have 5 children ages 10 to 14. Three of their children are in school.
He has been selling bread for 8 years.
This is his second loan with Turame. With this loan, posted on Kiva, he will increase his working capital and buy bread to sell in order to make more money.
In the next few years, he would like to become a clothing importer and see his children study.

loans.use: to buy more bread.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay tuition fees for her son who wants to pursue a Bachelor's degree, majoring in information technology.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda lives in San Martin, puebla with her husband, Martin Guadalupe. Imelda works as the town chiropractor and sees her patients in her house. Imelda and her husband have lived in the same home for over 15 years. They are very proud of what their hard work has given them. However, the tin roof they have gives them a lot of problems. The first one is the cold nights during winter and the lack of shelter the tin roof provides. The other reason is that Imelda thinks is it not the right environment to receive patients. They have been saving to replace the roof for a proper cement roof. They need the loan to finish buying the materials needed. Given the informality of Imelda's job and her age she has no access to credit from other institutions. They will receive technical training and supervision to make sure the construction meets all the quality and safety standards. Imelda wishes to finally have a place she can feel extremely proud of and where she can receive her patients.

loans.use: to replace her home's tin roof with a cement roof

loans.name: Khatuna

texts.en:
Khatuna is 32-years-old divorced woman from the city of Rustavi. She has a school-aged daughter and leads the family on her own. Khatuna works as a sales lady at the local store and generates 250 GEL monthly. As it becomes hard to earn a living with this insignificant income, Khatuna decided to start her own business and generate additional income. 

Khatuna requested a loan from Credo to start a trading business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative by Kiva and Credo. The startup loan program envisages provisions for business startup and re-startup credits with soft conditions for the country's poor people, who, regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income, do not have access to credit products. With the received credit, Khatuna will purchase a stock of linens at wholesale prices in Turkey and will sell in her community with price mark-ups.

The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva startup loan, will significantly increase the family's income. Their income will double, and the family members will be able to improve their living conditions. Khatuna and her daughter rely on the goodwill of lenders and highly appreciate their help.

loans.use: To begin trading linens to get additional income

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to process and store palm oil products.

loans.name: Jose Eduardo

texts.en:
Jose Eduardo lives in a community in the Department of Intibucá Honduras. He is dedicated to agriculture (Coffee and vegetables). Age 25 years; he is unmarried. It is clear that Jose Eduardo works hard to maintain his family and at night, after a hard day of work, the conditions in the house are not very good due to the lack of electricity. He hopes that the solar energy system will improve the living conditions.
Jose Eduardo is requesting a loan to purchase a complete solar electric system from SOLUZ Honduras, that will permit him to have a better lighting, charge his cell phones, and saving in traditional energy expenditure.

loans.use: to purchase a solar home system that will allow him to reduce spending in kerosene, candles, and improve the home lighting.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to process and store palm oil products.

loans.name: Awa's Group

texts.fr:
Créer le 07 Janvier 1997, ce banc villageois est l’un des plus anciens dans le système. Actuellement une relève est entrain de prendre les activités en main. Les femmes vivent dans le même  quartier. Il existe une bonne connexion entre les membres du groupe. Elles s’activent principalement dans le petit commerce et la transformation de produits locaux.

Madame Awa (debout à droite avec une main levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est âgée de 58 ans, est mariée et mère de 05 enfants : 03 garçons et 02 filles. Elle s’active dans la vente de glace, elle est l’une des principaux clients de la boulangerie de son quartier. Elle fait aussi des jus de fruits à  base de produits agricoles : bissap, gingembre, pain de singe. Elle jouit d’une bonne expérience dans ce  commerce. 
 
Avec son nouveau crédit, elle compte acheter des sachets pour la glace, un sac de sucre, trois bassines de bissap, 5 kg de gingembre et divers colorants alimentaires.

Avec les bénéfices que cette activité génère, elle compte dans le futur renforcer son épargne aider son mari dans les taches régaliennes (dépenses), assurer la scolarité des enfants et leurs soins.
texts.en:
Created on January 7, 1997, this banc villageois is one of the oldest in the system. A replacement is currently taking over the business activities. The women live in the same neighborhood. There is a good connection between the group members. They mainly work in small trade and in the processing of local products. 

Awa (standing on the right with her arm raised), is the group's star borrower. She is 58 years old, is married with 5 children: 3 boys and 2 girls. She sells ice-cream and she is one of the main customers of the bakery in her neighborhood. She also makes fruit juices from a base of agricultural products: hibiscus flower, ginger, and baobab fruit. She has a lot of experience in this business. 

With her new loan, she wants to buy bags for ice-cream, a bag of sugar, three basins of hibiscus flowers, 5 kg of ginger, and a variety of food coloring. 

With the earnings generated from this activity, she hopes to build up her savings in the future, help her husband with expenses and ensure school and care for her children.

loans.use: to buy bags for ice-cream, a bag of sugar, three basins of hibiscus flowers, 5 kg of ginger, and a variety of food coloring.

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita  engages in producing crab traps, locally known as "panggal". They are  made  purely of bamboo materials. She is a 55-year-old married woman living in the town of Talibon, Bohol.

She is  asking for a loan to buy additional materials  like bamboo. These will help Julita produce and sell more crab traps to her respective customers.  With these, she will be able to handle her finances and start to roll back her capital to other business ventures.

She dreams of expanding her business to make it productive and profitable for sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: to buy additional materials  like bamboo for weaving crab traps

loans.name: Laserna

texts.en:
Laserna is a 54-year-old married mother of 5 grown children from Ajuy, Iloilo in the Philippines. 

Laserna helps her husband in their fishing venture. This has been the sole source of their income for the past 30 years. 

Laserna is requesting a loan to buy fishing materials such as nets, hooks, and floaters. A loan will allow Laserna and her husband to improve their fishing business as well as their income. 

In the future, Laserna hopes to expand their fishing business in order to generate more revenue.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials such as nets, hooks, and floaters.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn is a merchant from Ajuy, Iloilo. She is 40 years old, married and has six children. Analyn earns a living through her retail sales of groceries, toys, kitchen utensils, wheel tires, and other items.

Analyn is asking to take a loan to buy more stock to sell such as slippers, children’s toys, accessories, kitchen utensils, toiletries, wheel tires for motorcycles, and groceries such as rice, canned goods, noodles, soap, and detergents. This loan will help Analyn to improve her inventories, thus attracting more buyers in her store. Moreover, she will be able to sell more products for a good price, thus augmenting her income and profit.

In the future, Analyn hopes to make her business more stable and profitable. She also wants to save money for her children’s schooling.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell such as slippers, children’s toys, accessories, kitchen utensils, toiletries, wheel tires for motorcycles, and groceries such as rice and canned goods.

loans.name: Gulbony

texts.en:
Gulbony was born in 1971. She is married and has three children. She is a highly-educated woman. 

Gulbony has worked for more than 20 years in a local school. She had dreamed to be a teacher since childhood and she realized her dream 20 years ago when she started to work in a school. Gulbony is one of the successful and smart teachers. She has many pupils and they like her classes very much. 

Gulbony now needs financial support because she is ill and she must treat herself. She is asking for a loan of TJS 1,500 (somoni) to buy medicine for treatment. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy medicine for treatment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy silk yarn and textiles for her sewing workshop.

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen is a married woman and she has five children who don't attend school because they are all grown-ups. Together, they live in their own house that  has electricity and piped water. 

Ellen has operated a tailoring business for the past 25 years. Her potential clients are women and men. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. 

With the KES 20,000 loan, Ellen wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies, certified potato seeds, and to care for her crops.

loans.name: Benedict

texts.en:
Meet Benedict from Kapsowar, Kenya. He is a farmer from a community not known for farming, but, nevertheless, he is earning a living through agriculture. He is happily married, and, together with his wife, they are blessed with a lovely family. 

For the past 5 years, Benedict has been practicing mixed farming. And, because of his experience, Benedict both commands a lot of respect from fellow farmers and is regarded as a mentor. 

Income from selling milk, eggs, and maize has allowed him to earn a decent income. Benedict passionately loves dairy farming, and he has named animals on his farm, such as Lelmet, his dairy cow. Milking and feeding Lelmet makes him very proud. By selling milk, he earns good returns, and the demand for milk has been expanding. Through extensive use of his mobile phone, he receives orders from customers and then sends his customers a text message when the milk is ready for collection. 

Demand has been overwhelming, and Benedict needs an additional cow to satisfy his orders. He is requesting a loan to buy a good quality dairy cow. Benedict does not intend to buy just an ordinary cow; he wants to buy a distinct breed that is easy to manage and has a natural ability to produce rich, creamy milk. The cow he plans to buy will produce between 15 to 20 liters of milk a day. 

The increased milk production will translate into more income, and Benedict will be able to improve his living conditions and secure the future of his siblings going to school. In addition, Benedict hopes that if his milk selling business keeps growing at a good rhythm, he will be able to create at least one job on his farm for someone without job opportunities.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Máxima Margarita

texts.es:
Máxima, de 32 años de edad, estudió hasta noveno grado, la falta de apoyo económico le obligo a no continuar su formación académica, es madre soltera y tiene un hijo, la relación con su pareja no funciono y decidieron separarse, el niño va a kínder, ella lo lleva y lo trae a la escuela.- Actualmente, vive con su mamá y hermanos, pero solo su hijo depende de ella. 

Se dedica al comercio de ropa usada, tiene un puesto en el mercado del pueblo, en el  cual solo vende los días sábados y domingos, ya que en esos días es cuando más se logra vender,  ya tiene un año de dedicarse a este negocio, tener ingresos económicos para su hijo la llevo a tomar esta decisión.- Su mamá le apoyó en el inicio, comprando ella la mercadería y ella la vendía.

La distancia que recorre para llegar a donde tiene el puesto de trabajo es de 50 km, ya que es en otro departamento muy retirado de donde vive; viaja en bus y su madre la ayuda siempre comprando la ropa, para que Máxima la venda.- El horario de venta es de 7:00 a.m. a 5:00 p.m. 

El préstamo lo necesita para comprar pantalones, camisas, ropa interior, calcetines, etc.- En esta época de fin de año, las ventas incrementan, es por esa razón que quiere comprar más ropa para ofrecer más variedad a sus clientes.

Sus sueños a futuro son, darle la oportunidad a su hijo que estudie una carrera universitaria y apoyar a su madre en lo que este a su alcance.
texts.en:
Máxima is 32 years old and has 9th grade education. Lack of financial support obliged her to not continue her schooling. She is a single mother and has a son. The relationship with her partner did not work out and they decided to separate. The child goes to kindergarten she takes him to and from school.

She sells used clothing and has a stand in the town market town, where she only sells on Saturdays and Sundays, as those are the days she manages to sell the most. She has been working in this business for a year. Having income for her son led her to take this decision. Her mother helped her in the beginning, by buying her the merchandise, and she would sell it. 

The distance she travels to get to where she has her stand is 50 km, as it is in another department quite far from where she lives. She travels by bus and her mother helps her by always buying clothing for Maxima to sell. 

Her hours of sale are from 7 AM to 5 PM. She needs a loan in order to buy pants, shirts, underwear, socks, etc. At this year end time of year, sales increase, and that is why she wants to buy more clothing so that she can offer more selection to her customers. Her future dreams are to provide opportunity to her son so that he can study toward a university degree, and to support her mother to the extent she can.

loans.use: To buy pants, shirts, underwear, socks, etc.

loans.name: Fares

texts.en:
Fares is a 26-year-old, single young man who lives with his family in a rented house in Hodeidah city, Yemen. He studied until secondary education, but couldn't complete his study.

Now, he operates a business of selling ready-made women’s clothes in a small store. Fares earns a good amount of money from this business, but most of what he earns goes to cover the necessary expenses of the family. Fares' capital is small, and that stops him up front from expanding his business and attracting a lot of customers. Therefore, he applied for a loan of 450,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase different kinds of new, stylish ready-made women's clothes for resale to his customers.

Fares looks forward to opening another store and buying a vehicle for his business.

loans.use: to purchase new, stylish ready-made women's clothes for resale to his customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Abla  Massanh

texts.fr: Revendeuse des détergents(omo et savons) depuis 2010, ABLA habite le quartier Adidogomé avec sa famille ; elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants et est âgée de 34 ans ;puis elle s’approvisionne deux fois par mois au marché d’Adidogomé et les revend à domicile. ABLA, dans le souci d’augmenter sa marge bénéficiaire, de mieux épargner et aider son ménage à mieux vivre, elle sollicite un microcrédit  pour réaliser ce rêve qu’elle espère voir naître.
texts.en:
A detergent seller (omo-brand cleaner and soap) since 2010, Abla lives in the Adidogomé neighbourhood with her family. She is married with three children. She is 34. She stocks up twice per month in the Adidogomé market and sells her products from home. 
Wanting to increase her small profit margin, and to better support her family, Abla is requesting a micro loan to realize this dream.

loans.use: to buy 5 dozen bottles of omo-brand cleaner and 4 cartons of soap.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase processed palm oil products.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to process and store palm oil products.

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.en: Dilafruz was born in the year of 1979. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a rental worker. Dilafruz decided to start a new business and in this way to earn a living. She is going to organize a business in animal husbandry. She lives in a village and has good opportunity to develop this business. Dilafruz will manage the business alone. She is asking for a loan of 2,000 somoni to buy cattle for organizing her new business. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: To buy cattle for organizing a new business

loans.name: Vicky Aneth

texts.es: Vicky es una mujer de 30 años de edad, madre de dos hijos de 8 y 2 años de edad, debido a la necesidad de generar ingresos para su familia,  desde el año 2010, está dedicada a vender al por mayor y al detal carnes frías, ella ofrece los productos en el barrio donde reside ubicado en el municipio de Barranquilla; se dirige casa por casa a ofrecer las carnes frías a las amas de casa, también ofrece a los trabajadores de empresas sus productos y brinda comodidad de pago.  Su horario de trabajo es de 2 p.m. a 5 p.m. y solo vende quincenalmente, ella compra sus productos de contado, sin embargo su capital le es insuficiente por eso está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará carnes frías para mejorar sus stock de producto y ampliar su cobertura.  Vicky desea a largo plazo tener un local donde pueda ofrecer sus productos y tener una mayor estabilidad, su meta familiar es poder pagar la educación de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Vicky is a 30 year old mother of two children, ages 2 and 8. Given the need to make money for her family, since 2010 she has worked selling cold cuts both wholesale and retail. She sells the products in the neighborhood where she resides in Barranquilla, going door to door offering the meats to housewives. She also sells them to employees at work and offers them convenient payment. She works from 2pm to 5pm and only sells semimonthly. 

She purchases a limited quantity of products; nevertheless, she doesn't have sufficient capital, and is therefore applying for this loan, her first from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, with which she will purchase cold cuts to improve her stock and increase her coverage. In the long run, Vicky wants to open a shop where she can sell her products and have more stability. Her goal for her family is to be able to pay for her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase cold cuts to improve her stock and increase her coverage

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing and footwear

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is a husband and father of four wonderful children. He's been in business for sixteen years selling dry goods in Buchanan.  He hopes selling SE4ALL products like clean cookstoves and small solar homes systems will be very profitable to the mosque. The Kiva loan allows him to obtain this SE4ALL product inventory and and make a profit, allowing him to easily repay his loan.

loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Om- Foud** Group

texts.en:
This group is called Om-Foud**. It consists of four women from city of Sana'a, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 200,000 YER from AMB.

Mona is the leader of the group. She is 46 years old, married and a mother of three children, living with her family in a humble house. She has studied up to secondary education, but couldn't complete her studies because she got married when she was very young. 

Mona works as a housewife, and her husband is an employee with a small salary in the private sector. Her house lacks a refrigerator, and her husband couldn't purchase one. For this reason, she applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase a refrigerator to keep water, drinks, and some foods in a cold condition.

Mona hopes to buy all home appliances.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator to keep water, drinks, and some foods in a cold condition.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Amjad

texts.en:
Amjad is a 25-year-old, single man from Qabatiya, a village near Jenin city. He has worked as a construction worker for the past two years. He now has good experience in this field. Amjad would like to improve his business and open his own construction service office in the future.

Amjad took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit & Development (FATEN). This loan will help him to buy some tools he needs in his construction work. By taking this loan, Amjad will be able to increase his productivity and also his income. 

Amjad appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy some tools he needs in his construction work.

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
Ailyn is a 34-year-old, married woman and a mother of two children, from Ajuy, Iloilo. She is engaged in retail sales of fruits, like bananas, processed goods, like hot dogs and sausages, and clothes. Ailyn has been in the business for more than five years now. This is the source of her income. 

Ailyn is asking to take a loan to buy more products, like bananas, hot dogs, and sausages, as well as clothes, like pants, dresses, fashion accessories, slippers, and sandals. This loan will help Ailyn improve her business and income. 

In the future, Ailyn hopes to make her business more profitable and stable. She also wants to save money for her children’s schooling.

loans.use: to buy more products, like bananas, hot dogs, and sausages, as well as clothes, like pants, dresses, fashion accessories, slippers, and sandals.

loans.name: Aminata's Group

texts.fr:
C e groupe est composé de femmes très déterminées dans leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Ces dernières ayant un long vécu dans le programme des bancs villageois ont su développer un esprit de solidarité leur permettant de nos jours de faire face à beaucoup de situations. Ce groupement est l’un des meilleurs de la région. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Aminata (en médaillon en haut et à droite), est l’emprunteuse vedette de ce groupe. Elle est  âgée de 30 ans,  elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants uniquement des filles.  C’est une femme très engagée dans les activités du groupement. Elle tient une boutique en Co gérance avec son frère de même père et mère.

Avec ce prêt elle compte renforcer sa boutique par l’achat: d’une tonne de riz soit 20 sacs de 50kg, 05 sacs d’oignon et de pomme de terre et divers autres produits de consommation courante. 

Les bénéfices de son activité lui permettront de mieux assoir son commerce, de renforcer son épargne et de mieux prendre en charge les préoccupations de ses enfants.
texts.en:
This group is made up of women who are very determined in their income-generating activities. They have a long background in the banc villageois program, having developed a spirit of solidarity allowing them to face many of today's situations.This grouping is one of the best in the region. Their main activity is small trade. 

Aminata (in the circle at the top-right corner), is the main borrower for this group. She is 30 years old, is married and a mother of 2 children, both girls. She is a woman who is very engaged in the group's activities. She has a store that she co-manages with her brother, who has same mother and father as her. 

With this loan, she expects to strengthen her store by purchasing: one ton of rice in the form of 20 bags of 50 kg, 5 bags of onions and potatoes and a variety of other common food products. 

The earnings from this activity will allow her to better establish her business, to build up her savings and to take over more of her children's concerns.

loans.use: to strengthen her store by purchasing: one ton of rice in the form of 20 bags of 50 kg, 5 bags of onions and potatoes and a variety of other common food products.

loans.name: Kayondo

texts.en:
Kayondo lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with 4 children who all go to school. She has no additional family members. 

Kayondo sells charcoal at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 2 years, working 7 days a week. 

Kayondo has requested a 200,000 UGX loan from Micro Credit for Development and Transformation SACCO in order to buy bags of charcoal. 

Kayondo's major challenges include transportation and seasonal demand. Her goal and aspiration is to buy van for transporting charcoal from her village to the market to sell. 

Kayondo lives in her own house, and the family has access to piped water and electricity. Her major monthly expenses include food and her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Jeanpaul

texts.en:
Jeanpaul is 36 years old. He is married with two children between the ages of three and five years. One of them goes to school. He is a farmer and has been farming for 17 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers to help him grow maize and beans to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for his children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en: Roselyn is a 49-year-old widow from Ajuy, Iloilo. She has three children. Roselyn operates a small sari-sari or retail store business selling various goods and items to the people in her place. Roselyn has been in the business for more than 13 years now. She would like to take a loan to buy more stock to sell such as rice, noodles, canned goods, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, chips and snack foods, condiments and cooking ingredients, fruits and vegetables.  A loan will help Roselyn in augmenting her inventory which will attract many buyers to her store. In the future Roselyn hopes to make her business more stable and productive.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell such as rice, noodles, canned goods, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, chips and snack foods, condiments and cooking ingredients.

loans.name: Duc

texts.en:
Duc would like to take a further loan to repair his house and invest more capital in his current business. Duc's previous loan enabled him to increase his sales and earn a higher income to support his family.

He hopes that another loan will assist him in increasing the size of his business, attract new customers, and increase sales. He also hopes that through the loan, he can increase his income and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to repair his house and invest more capital in his current business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Wendtoin De Koanga Group

texts.fr:
Madame WELEBRE est la représentante du groupe WENDTOIN DE KOANGA. Elle se porte très bien. Mariée, elle est mère de 05 enfants. Le plus âgé à 30 ans et le moins âgé à 15 ans. 01 va à l’école. Elle a 05 personnes en charges.
Madame vend des céréales depuis 03 ans. Elle s’approvisionne dans les marchés environnants. Ses clients son les habitants des quartiers  proches.
Elle veut s’acheter 02 sacs de mil ; 02 sacs de mil rouge.
Madame compte utiliser ses bénéfices pour investir dans con commerce. Elle ambitionne devenir une grossiste.
texts.en:
Madame Welebre is the representative of the group called Wendtoin de Koanga. She feels just fine. She is the married mother of five children. The oldest is 30 years old and the youngest 15 years old. One of them goes to school. Welebre is supporting five persons. 

Welebre has been selling cereals for three years. She buys her inventory in local markets. Her clients are people who live in nearby neighborhoods. She wants to buy two sacks of millet and two sacks of red millet.  

She intends to use her profit to invest in her business. Her ambition is to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: to buy two sacks de millet and two sacks of red millet

loans.name: Maximilla

texts.en:
Maximilla is a married woman and has four children who attend school. Together with her family, she lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. 

Maximilla has operated a tailoring business for the past ten years. Her potential clients are ladies and gents.

With the loan of KES 22,500 she wants to purchase household goods for resale. She mentioned seasonality and transportation as a major challenge. 

She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future.

loans.use: to purchase households goods for resale

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is a 37-year-old married woman and the mother of five children from Ajuy, Iloilo. She is engaged in making and selling rubber planting pots. Emily has been in the business for more than 12 years now. She uses scrap and used wheel tires to makes pots. She is requesting a loan to buy more used rubber tires to make planting pots. A loan will greatly help Emily to make her business more productive and profitable. In the future, she hopes to expand her business in order to generate more revenue. Moreover, she wants to save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy more used rubber tires to make planting pots

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Amtal

texts.en:
Amtal is the age of 36 and lives in Lahore with her husband and four children. Her husband has been running a barbershop for many years. He has grown old and his instruments have as well; worn out instruments need to be replaced with new ones. He wants to buy new instruments, but his financial condition does not allow him to buy them.

Due to his low purchasing power, Amtal requested a loan so that her husband can become empowered and can easily buy new instruments such as scissors, combs, a shaving machine, front mirror, and revolving chair.

Amtal hopes that this loan will work positively, and she would be able to make some savings for household expenses. Amtal thanks Kiva and field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy a front mirror, plastic chair, scissors, combs, shaving machine, etc. for her husband's barber shop.

loans.name: Shabana's Group

texts.en:
Shabana is a 38-year-old married woman. She has been doing embroidery by machine at home for the past five years to support her family. In fact her husband is also doing the same work at home but earns an insufficient income to support the family. That's why she helps her husband in his tasks related to the embroidery and she sells embroidered dresses in her town. By this time she has attained a regular list of customers and makes enough to contribute to the family income. She has become expert in embroidery by machine and wants more raw materials for embroidery so that she can easily cope with the increasing demand for her art.

She is the mother of two sons and two daughters. She hopes to get a boost in her earnings through her large sales. She wishes to utilize a portion of revenue to provide a quality education for her children.

Shabana thanks Kiva and field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to enhance her embroidery work.

loans.name: Women Of Faith Victory Group

texts.en:
In 2014, Women of Faith Victory Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to be trained in financial management and savings mobilization to help improve their livelihood.

The person raising her hand in the photograph is Gorret, a member of this group. She is thirty-five years old, married and living with her husband and her three children. She is a mixed farmer who does potato, maize and bean farming. She has applied for a loan to buy certified seeds and fertilizer so that she can improve crop yield. She hopes that this will help increase her income, thus enabling her to continue supporting her children's education.

Gorret is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for their help and support.

loans.use: to buy certified seeds and fertilizer that will help improve crop yield.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is 56 years old. She is married to Gregory and, together, they have been blessed with five children, with ages between 26 and 4 years.

Dorcas is a tailor, a business she has done for the last three years, earning a monthly income of KES 13,500.

Dorcas has requested her third loan with VisionFund Kenya, in the amount of KES 20,000, which she will use to buy more stocks of textile materials for dress-making.

With the anticipated profits, Dorcas will be able to improve her education.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to provide for her family's needs and to secure their future.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of textile materials for dress-making.

loans.name: Augustin

texts.en:
Augustin is 40 years old, a married man with five children between the ages of 4 and 18 years old. His children attend school. He has been farming for 15 years and will use this loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers to grow maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay his employees.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to use to grow maize to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Alphonse

texts.en:
Alphonse is 26 years old. He is married with one child who is one year old.

He has been farming for 7 years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers for growing maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his employees.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for growing maize to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 37 years old. She is married with 2 children aged between 5 and 8 years, and both of them go to school.

She has been farming for 13 years. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizers for growing maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay for her workers. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for growing maize to sell

loans.name: Dinna

texts.en:
Dinna is a 20-year-old single student  in the third year at university. She is from the Pursat province in Cambodia. Her mother grows rice and she also makes snack food to sell at a market. Her brother works in a factory.

Sshe doesn’t have enough finances to pay her university fees and therefore requests this  loan. This loan will help her graduate successfully with skills to build her future. After graduation, she hopes to have a job with a decent salary, so she will be able to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to pay her university fees.

loans.name: Elvia Rubenia

texts.en:
Elvia Rubenia lives in a community in the Department of Intibucá Honduras. She is dedicated to agriculture (coffee). Age 46 years; she is married and has six children. It is clear that Elvia Rubenia works hard to maintain her family and at night, after a hard day of work, the conditions in the house are not very good due to the lack of electricity. She hopes that with the solar energy system, her children will be able to continue studying and improve the living conditions.
Elvia Rubenia is requesting a loan to purchase a complete solar electric system from SOLUZ Honduras, that will permit to have a better lighting, charge her cell phones, and saving in traditional energy expenditure.

loans.use: to purchase a solar home system that will allow her to reduce spending in kerosene, candles, and improve the home lighting.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to process and store palm oil products.

loans.name: Jesa

texts.en: Jesa is a 36-year-old married woman from Ajuy, Iloilo. She has six children. Jesa  earns a living through her scrap buying business. She buys and sells scrap and recyclable materials like empty bottles of soft drinks, cans, metal and steel, sacks and others. She is requesting a loan to buy scrap and recyclable materials like empty bottles of soft drinks, cans, metal and steel, sacks and others. A loan will help Jesa improve her business as well as her income. In the future, she hopes to improve her livelihood and save money to pay for her children’s schooling.

loans.use: to buy scrap and recyclable materials like empty bottles of soft drinks, cans, metal and steel, sacks and others.

loans.name: Erlita

texts.en: Erlita is a 48-year-old married woman and the mother of four grownup children. She lives in the town of Ajuy, Iloilo. Erlita has been engaged in the fishing business with her husband for more than 20 years now. She also earns an additional income through retail sales of rice. Erlita is asking to take a loan to buy fishing materials like nets, hooks, floaters and lead weights and additional rice. She believes that a loan will help her improve her stock of rice thus allowing her to sell more as well as augment their catch from fishing. In the future, she hopes to improve their livelihood.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like nets, hooks, floaters and lead weights and additional rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Al- Maha 14 October Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al- Maha 14 October and is composed of five women who live in Taiz city, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 230,000 YER from AMB.

The president of the group is Maha, who is 33 years old. The house where she lives with her family is small and not enough for all the members of the family. Her husband is busy covering the daily needs of the family and his income is not enough to make the necessary expansion for the house by building another room inside the house. She feels ashamed about this condition, especially if any guest comes to their house. As a result, Maha applied for a loan of 30,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase construction supplies to make an extra room.

Maha's dream is seeing her oldest child in the university.

loans.use: To purchase construction supplies to make an extra room.

loans.name: Mark

texts.en:
Mark is a 30-year-old  ambitious, enterprising, and a go-getting farmer.  He lives in the Kitale area of Kenya with his wife and two lovely angels (Michel and Caren).

He has farmed for  ten years and sells eggs and crops.  He also has a motorcycle business to make ends meet.

Mark loves farming and has even nicknamed his cow and he really takes good care of his dairy cows. The Kitale area has favorable conditions for horticulture farming. The area has good soil, climate, a good transportation system, and a ready market for horticulture products. 

Mark wants to take advantage and start horticultural farming. He requests a loan to start horticulture farming. He intends to buy good vegetable and fruit seeds that he will use in horticultural farming. He will be able to improve his living conditions and secure the future of his children. The financial benefits that Mark will reap are almost immediate, and hence he will be assured of a secure future. He plans to start exporting his horticulture to international markets once he has accumulated more profits.

loans.use: to start horticulture farming.

loans.name: Millie

texts.en: Millie is a 36-year-old sari-sari store owner from Ajuy, Iloilo. She is married and has four children. Millie has operated her retail store for more than 13 years now. This is the source of her income. Her husband works as a fisherman. Millie is asking to take a loan to buy stock for her store like rice, canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries and new fishing nets. A loan will help her improve her business as well as her income. In the future, Millie hopes to make her business a success.

loans.use: to buy stock for her store like rice, canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries and new fishing nets.

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is a 32-year-old married woman, and mother of four children. She is living happily with her family in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband owns an embroidery shop. He has been selling embroidery material for many years. He sells sequins, pearls, threads, precious stones, silk, needles and wooden frames for embroidery. The embroidery material for bridal dresses is very expensive, but its turnover is very high. 

Due to high cost, he is facing a shortage of materials and is unable to purchase the expensive raw materials to sell. Therefore, Nasreen has requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner, BRAC Pakistan, so that her husband can remove the shortage of embroidery materials. Through this amount her husband will buy stock of threads, fancy cloth, sequins, precious stones, and pearls of various colors. Nasreen is very thankful to the Kiva and field partner BRAC Pakistan

loans.use: to buy threads, sequins, and pearls for her husband's embroidery shop.

loans.name: Women / Men Of Hope Group

texts.en:
Phelister is a 38-year-old married woman with 2 children.  She is shown in the photo with her hand raised, and is a member of Women/Men of Hope Group. She works hard to support her family. 

She has bought and sold vegetables from local farmers and supplies them to the city market for 2 years. Phelister requests a loan to purchase  vegetable . She has a good customer base  and  hopes that her business will help support her family by improving their overall living standard. She wants to provide. better clothing, housing, and medical care. 

She is happy for Kiva and the support of their lenders.

loans.use: to buy vegetables.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 52 years old. She is married to Thomas and together they have been blessed with 4 children with ages between 24 and 15 years respectively.

Alice is a retail trader, a business she has done for the last 5 years, earning a monthly income of 24,000 KES. Alice has requested her 5th loan with VisionFund Kenya of 30,000 KES which she will use to purchase stock of assorted household retail goods for resale at a profit.

With the anticipated profits, Alice will be able to repay her loan as well as uplift the living standards of her family. Her hope and dream for the future is to become financially stable.

loans.use: to purchase stock of retail goods

loans.name: Salina

texts.en:
Salina is 38 years old and a single mother of three children. She has a tailoring business which she has been running for three years. Right now, she makes a monthly income of KES 10,000. 

Salina will use this loan to buy textile materials, sewing thread, and buttons to make clothes to sell. She will use the anticipated profits from her business to educate her children. 

This is Salina's first loan from VisionFund Kenya. In the future, Salina hopes to expand her business and to be successful.

loans.use: to buy textile materials for use in her business.

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es: Guadalupe de 40 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus tres hijos, se dedica a la crianza de ganado lechero, ella quiere mejorar su vivienda encementando el lugar que muestra en la fotografía ya que por la lluvias se hace mucho lodo, pero no tiene suficiente capital para poder realizarlo por eso solicita un crédito para la compra de cemento, arena, ladrillos y pago de mano de obra par que ella y su familia puedan vivir mas cómodos.
texts.en:
Guadalupe is 40 years old, and she lives in her own house with her husband and her three children. She makes a living raising dairy cattle. 

Guadalupe wants to improve her home by installing a cement pad in the area shown in the photo, since the rain creates a lot of mud there. She doesn't have sufficient capital to complete this project. As a result, she is requesting a loan to buy cement, sand, bricks, and pay for the labor costs, so she and her family can live more comfortably.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, bricks, and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Al- Ahd Al- Jadid Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al- Ahd Al- Jadid. It consists of four women from Sana'a city, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 200,000 YER from AMB.

Iman is the leader of the group, a single woman with a diploma certificate living with her parents in an old house. Her father is the breadwinner of the family, but his income is limited. A long time ago, he started to renovate that old house, but he couldn't complete that renovation because most of what money he earns goes to cover the necessary needs of the family.

Iman decided to help him complete the rest of the renovations of the house. For this reason, she applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase construction supplies to complete the renovation of the house. Iman hopes to expand her house through building new rooms.

loans.use: to purchase construction supplies to complete the renovation of the house

loans.name: Esha

texts.en:
Esha is a married woman and has five children who don't attend school because they are all grownups. Together with her family, they live at their own  house that has electricity and piped water. 

Esha has operated a tailoring business for the past 25 years. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. 

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman and she has one child who attends school. Her husband is a businessman and, together, they live in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. 

Fatuma has operated a tailoring business for the past seven years. Her potential clients are women and men. Her dream is to establish a boutique in the future. 

With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Ghulam  Fatima

texts.en: Ghulam Fatima is a 52-year-old, married woman. She works doing hand embroidery. She makes beautiful patterns for the people of her community. Her designs are much in demand and she has managed to consolidate a clientele that allows her to contribute to the expenses of her home. To help her to continue her operations, she has requested for a loan of 45,000 PKR  in order to buy spools of threads in different colors and packs of beads, sequins and stones for embellishment which will allow her to cater to more customers consistently. She is hopeful to get an increase in her income by targeting more customers. She dreams for her bright future and desires to build her own house.

loans.use: to buy spools of threads in different colors and packs of beads, sequins and stones forembellishmen which will allow her to cater to more customers consistently.

loans.name: Paz Y Progreso Group

texts.es: Esta es la Alcancía “Paz Y Progreso” está constituida por 10 mujeres solidarias y optimistas. Norma de 42 años  de edad es separada con 01 hijo dependiente. Actualmente se dedica a la venta de jugos. Así mismo como actividad secundaria se dedica al cuidado de niños y del hogar. Su mayor anhelo es de contar con una tienda de abarrotes. En esta oportunidad solicitó el crédito para la compra de naranjas, piñas y papaya.  El grupo “Paz Y Progreso” agradecen por el apoyo brindado a los inversionistas Kiva. Norma se encuentra de pie es la tercera del lado izquierdo y viste polo con rayas  celeste y rosado.
texts.en:
This is the “Paz y Progreso” [Peace and Progress] bank.  It is made up of ten supportive and optimistic women.  

Norma, age 42, is separated, with one dependent child.  She currently works selling juice.  Additionally, as another line of work, she cares for children and homes.  Her greatest desire is to have a small grocery store.  

At this point in time, she is asking for a loan to buy oranges, pineapples, and papaya.  The Paz y Progreso group is thankful for the support given by Kiva investors.  Norma is standing third from the left, wearing a shirt with blue and pink stripes.

loans.use: to buy oranges, pineapples, and papaya.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more repair parts for his store.

loans.name: Fatou's Group

texts.fr:
C e groupe est composé de femmes très déterminées dans leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Ces dernières ayant un long vécu dans le programme des bancs villageois ont su développer un esprit de solidarité leur permettant de nos jours de faire face à beaucoup de situations. Ce groupement est l’un des meilleurs de la région. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Fatou (assise à deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche avec la main gauche levée) est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est  fait partie des jeunes les plus dynamiques du groupement, elle est célibataire et sans enfant. Elle s’active dans la vente pagne traditionnel pour femme, d’encens et divers produits de beauté. Elle a une bonne connaissance du domaine et s’approvisionne à la capitale et dans les régions frontalières du  sud est.  
 
Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter une trentaine de mètre de tissus uniques, divers fils de couleur, des paquets de 12 déodorants.

Les bénéfices de son activité lui permettront d’assurer un soutien à sa mère dans la gestion de la  dépense quotidienne, de satisfaire ses besoins personnels et accroître son épargne en vu de rendre pérenne ses activités.
texts.en:
This group is made up of women who are very determined in their income-generating activities. They have a long background in the banc villageois program, having developed a spirit of solidarity allowing them to face many of today's situations.This grouping is one of the best in the region. Their main activity is small trade.

Fatou (sitting in the front row, second from the right with her arm raised) is the group's main borrower. She is a part of the most dynamic youth in the group, and is single without children. Her business consists of selling traditional pagnes for women, incense and a variety of beauty products. She has a good understanding of the field and she gets her stock from the capital and from the south-east border regions. 

With this loan she expects to buy approximately 30 meters of unique fabrics, different colored threads, packets of 12 deodorants. 

The earnings from this activity will allow her to ensure support for her mother in the management of daily expenses, to satisfy her personal needs and to build up her savings in order to make her business sustainable.

loans.use: to buy approximately 30 meters of unique fabrics, different colored threads, packets of 12 deodorants.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is a married woman with 4 children, all attend school.

 She sells charcoal at the market and has  been in  business for 2 years. She works seven days a week and requests 200,000 UGX from MCDT – SACCO to buy large quantities of used clothing. Her major challenge includes seasonal changes and transportation. 

Her goal  is to buy plot of land to start farming. She lives in her own house  which has access to running water and electricity. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy large quantities of used clothing.

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with two children and both go to school. She has no additional members. She sells charcoal and green bananas at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 18 years. She works seven days a week. 

She has requested for a loan of 200,000 UGX from MCDT – SACCO to buy bags of charcoal and bunches of green bananas. Her major challenges include seasonality and transportation. Her goal and aspiration is to buy land for farming. She lives in rented house and the family has no access to piped water or electricity. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy bags of charcoal and bunches of green bananas.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 64 years old, married, and has two children. He is smallholder farmer based in Kericho, which is an agricultural center near the famous Rift valley. He owns a small piece of land, which he farms with his wife. They keep dairy cattle and grow maize, which they have been doing for 10 years. Their main income sources are milk and crops. To earn additional income, Peter recently ventured into a farm produce-motorcycle transportation business. 

Peter requested a loan for 30,000 KES, which he will use to expand his horticulture business. Horticultural produce and processed products from the developing world are becoming increasingly popular in international markets, evident from the steadily rising exports. While experience shows that horticulture offers good opportunities for poverty reduction, because it increases employment and generates income, the government takes little care to ensure that small and poor farmers are not excluded from the opportunities in this market sector. It is against this backdrop that Juhudi has teamed up with Kiva to provide Peter with access to a loan facility that will assist him to expand his horticulture farm into a highly profitable business, increase employment opportunities, and bring about increasing commercialization of the rural sector. Peter’s family will benefit from the growth and diversification of their family business. This will not only increase their income, but also reduce their income vulnerability.

loans.use: to expand his horticulture farm

loans.name: King'atua Grazers Self Help Group

texts.en:
In 2012 a group named Kingatua Grazers Self Help Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to be trained on savings management and financial management.

Beth (shown raising her hand in the photograph) is one of the group members.   She is a fifty one-year-old married woman blessed with four children and living with them.

She had previously borrowed from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa -enterprise incubation fund and repaid promptly. She is borrowing from Kiva to buy fertilizer and pesticides to boost her farming. She hopes this will lead to a bountiful harvest and more income.  She hopes to improve her living standards and provide better health care, good clothing, and a balanced diet for her family.

Beth is grateful to Kiva and the entire lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is a 32-year-old married woman, and a mother of three children from Ajuy, Iloilo. She has been engaged in a tricycle transport business with her husband for more than 15 years now. This is the source of their income. 

Analiza is asking for a loan to pay for the repair of the tricycle, and to buy spare parts like wheels, tires, nut and bolts, chains, etc.  This loan will help Analiza and her husband in improving their business, thus augmenting their income and profits. In the future, Analiza hopes to make their business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for her children’s schooling.

loans.use: to buy spare parts like wheels, tires, nut and bolts, chains, etc.

loans.name: Angel

texts.en:
Angel, 27 years old and married has two children aged 5 and 4 years old. To support the needs of the family and to ensure that they are able to finance the education of their children, Angel helps her husband in managing their clothes store. 

Before venturing in the clothes selling business, Angel and her husband previously owned and managed a shop that sold DVD tapes and mobile phone accessories. This business was not good for them, as the mark up on the goods are low and therefore giving them only a small amount of income. From their savings and the sales from the left-over stocks of DVD tapes and mobile phone accessories, Angel and her husband decided to invest in selling clothes. The business started off well and Angel was pleased to see that the income potential was also good.

In 2010, she joined SEED after being invited by a neighbor who is a group leader of SEED in the community. Consequently, she was able to avail a first loan of PhP 5,000 which she used to buy additional stocks for her clothing sales business focusing on ladies' wear such as blouses and dresses. With due diligence in repayment and savings, Angel was able to increase her credit line with SEED. To date, on her 8th loan cycle, Angel plans to buy additional stocks of jeans, dresses, and shirts. These items were highly demanded by her customers in time for the holiday season. Angel knew that her sales are going to be good in as much as people would rather buy from clothing stores such as hers in as much as she sells in bargain compared to malls and department stores.       

Angel plans to finsih off the loan in just 18 months. By that time, it will be the season for school opening and she plans to invest in selling shoes and other footwear for school-aged children and teens. Angel expresses that she needs to plan ahead, study well the trends in her business, work hard and maintain her good credit and savings record for her to be able to operate her business with an increased return of income. With this, Angel is also assured that she and her husband will be able to continuously provide good education to their children and hopes that with it a better future for the whole family.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of dresses and shirts that are highly demanded by customers of her store during the holiday season.

loans.name: Carmencita

texts.en:
In June 2014, Carmencita was able to acquire a PhP 15,000 loan from KIVA. With the loan amount, Carmencita was able to buy rice, sugar and cooking oil in volumes. The stock helped Carmencita get by with the expected price inflation in the market. As she was able to stock ahead these items, Carmencita was able to maintain the price of her commodities even when other stores in the area have increased their prices. Consequently, Carmencita was able to not only retain but increase her customers and income.

For Carmencita, better sales is not the end all of the benefits of KIVA's loan extended to her. More importantly, the increased income has helped Carmencita to support the medical needs of her nephew who has a disability. To date, Carmencita is able to send her nephew in the country's biggest public hospital for therapy. Not only that, Carmencita was ablso able to support her brother who had medical needs after suffering from stroke.

On her third loan now, Carmencita is availing a PhP 17,000 loan. This time she wants to buy canned goods, toiletry items such as bath and laundry soap and soda drinks which are also highly demanded in her store. Having these items in her store would prop her income by 2 - 3% more of what she is earning today. 

Carmencita works hard to support her family who needs her most for their medical needs. At the same time, Carmencita saves to ensure that when the time comes that ailment will fall on her and with the coming of her age, she is most prepared financially.

loans.use: To buy canned goods, toiletries and soda drinks which are demanded in her store by customers.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to process and store palm oil products.

loans.name: Bessy

texts.en:
Bessy lives in a community in the Department of Intibucá Honduras. She is dedicated to agriculture (potatoes). Age 18 years; she is married. It is clear that Bessy works hard to maintain her family and at night, after a hard day of work, the conditions in the house are not very good due to the lack of electricity. She hopes that with the solar energy system, improve the living conditions.
Bessy is requesting a loan to purchase a complete solar electric system from SOLUZ Honduras, that will permit to have a better lighting, charge her cell phones, and saving in traditional energy expenditure.

loans.use: to purchase a solar home system that will allow her to reduce spending in kerosene, candles, and improve the home lighting.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian lives in a community in the Department of Intibucá Honduras. She is dedicated to Agriculture (coffee and corn). Age 48 years; she is married and has five children. It is clear that Lilian works hard to maintain her family and at night, after a hard day of work, the conditions in the house are not very good due to the lack of electricity. She hopes that with the solar energy system, her children will be able to continue studying and improve the living conditions.
Lilian is requesting a loan to purchase a complete solar electric system from SOLUZ Honduras, that will permit to have a better lighting, charge her cell phones, and saving in traditional energy expenditure.

loans.use: to purchase a solar home system that will allow her to reduce spending in kerosene, candles, and improve the home lighting.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 43 years old and married,. Together with her spouse, she been blessed with 2 children. She also supports 5 members of her family.

Joyce sells clothes in Kapsabet town and has been in the farming business for 6 years. She will use this loan to buy more stocks of clothes to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children and also to repay the loan.

This is her first loan from VisionFund Kenya. Her future hopes are to expand her business, make more income, and be able to support her family.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of clothes to sell

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is grateful that she was granted a 30,000 PHP loan, which she used to purchase various grocery items and products needed in her general store. She is glad that through her earnings she is able to send her children to school and meet their daily living expenses. 

She would now like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan, which she will use to buy large quantities of grocery items like rice, coffee, soda, rice noodles, fruits and vegetables, etc. which she sells at retail. She knows that more items in her store will yield more sales, and thus increase her earnings. Her income from her store is a stable source to sustain her family's basic needs and for the education of her children. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her. She wishes everyone a Blessed New Year!

Gina dreams to grow her business and become prosperous to give her children the best education. She prays for a happy and godly life. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital  and repay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of fish, fruits, and vegetables etc. needed in her business.

loans.name: Escomeñitas Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ESCOMEÑITAS” iniciará el cuarto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Achacachi, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Amalia es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: tienda de ferretería, venta de comida, venta de frutas, tienda de barrio, venta de pollos.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Amalia es integrante, ella indica que es el tercer año que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una asesora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio venta de comida; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió hace varios años, aprendiendo el mismo de sus padres a quienes desde niña apoyaba,  con un pequeño capital, el cual fue incrementando poco a poco con los créditos obtenidos en Pro Mujer.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de arroz y fideo por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su puesto de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The "ESCOMEÑITAS" communal bank will begin its fourth loan cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Achacachi regional hub. The group consists of eight members and is led by a board of directors, where Amalia serves as the chairwoman.  

The businesses in which the members of the communal bank work are varied. They include running a hardware store, selling food, selling fruits, running a neighbourhood store, and selling chickens.

The loan that the group will take out will benefit the owners of small microbusinesses, including Amalia. She says that this is her third year with Pro Mujer and that she became a member at the invitation of a consultant from the institution who went to visit her at her home. Currently, she runs a business selling food. She mentions that she started this business many years ago with a small capital, which she gradually increased with the loans she got from Pro Mujer. She learned the business from her parents, whom she used to help from a very young age.

The loan that she will take out now is to increase her capital by purchasing rice and noodles wholesale, which she will acquire from the wholesale vendors from the city of La Paz. Then, after cooking the products, she will sell them at her food stall. This line of work allows her to generate the means to support her family financially, as she is married and has three children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes the training offered by the institution.

loans.use: to purchase rice and noodles wholesale.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is 35 years old, married and together with his spouse they have been blessed with two children. He does farming in Kapsabet town and he has been in this business for four years.

He plans to use this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for use on his farm. He will use the anticipated profits to expand his farming business by buying more farm inputs.

This is Joel's first loan term from VisionFund Kenya and his future hopes are to grow his business and be successful, make more income and improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Enma Piedad

texts.es: A sus 60 años de edad Piedad es una señora casada, tiene 6 hijos pero ya todos son independientes y viven aparte, Piedad y su esposo se dedican a la venta de frutas desde hace 20 años atrás, doña Piedad cuenta que le va bien en este  negocio ya que asi ha podido sacar adelante a sus hijos, el dinero del crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de frutas para ofrecerlos en su puesto, la aspiración de Piedad es que mejore su negocio y seguir trabajando  junto a su esposo para sus gastos  ahora que viven solos.
texts.en:
At age sixty, Piedad is a married woman with six children, who are all adults and live on their own. Piedad and her husband have been working selling fruit for the past twenty years. She says that the business is going well for her and that it allowed her to provide for her children.

Piedad will invest the money from this loan in purchasing fruit to sell at her stand. Her goals are for her business to improve and to continue working alongside her husband in order to cover their expenses, since they now live alone.

loans.use: to buy fruit.

loans.name: Angustia

texts.en:
Angustia, 50 years old, married to an auto painter, has four children of whom 2 are currently studying. 

As Angustia's husband is earning only a meager amount which hardly suffice their daily needs, Angustia decided to put up her own business of selling bottled water. Starting up with only 10 gallons of water sold per week, Angustia patiently dealt with the business and learned the trade. At first, the income coming from the business helped Angustia to support the transportation expenses of her children going to and from the school. However, realizing that she can earn more if she can invest in other businesses, Angustia began looking for other sources of funds to invest for her planned business of a general store.

It was at this time, in 2010, that Angustia came across SEED through one of its employees conducting promotion activities in the area. Angustia completed the necessary orientation seminars and finally availed a PhP 4,000 loan at the start. With the funds now, Angustia was able to set up a general store in her house. Again, Angustia tried to learn the trade noting on competition and credit concerns among customers and with due diligence was able to repay back her loan. Angustia availed reloans thereafter which steadily increased the volume of her stocks. 

However, after a particular visit from an employee of SEED, Angustia realized that there are more potentials in terms of income should she invest in food production. The employee took time to coach her on the how much she could earn should she pursue her plan of producing food items. She listened and put into action what she learned. With this knowledge, Angustia began to study the production of dumplings and burger patties. On her 4th loan, Angustia funded this business and was more than happy with the income she earned. To date, Angustia earns a net of PhP 5,000 per day from her combined businesses of general store and food production. Not only that, Angustia was able to give employment to two neighbors. One was helping her with the actual food production while the other one was helping her as a sales staff in her business. 

Opening a branch in front of a public national high school where she lives, the demand for Angustia's products became higher. Students would often flock her stall buying food for snacks or lunch. It is in this context that Angustia needed to buy additional food steamers to process her dumplings and burger patties and a freezer to keep her stocks. These will be what Angustia is planning to buy on her 6th loan now amounting to PhP 30,000. 

In the future, Angustia plans to open a business with which she can partner with and optimize her husband's skills in auto painting. For now, Angustia is intent to improve her current business, earn well and support her family's needs while also giving some employment opportunity in her community. Indeed, as Mark Twain once said and as Angustia's business history embodies, "The success of getting ahead is getting started."

loans.use: To buy additional food steamers and a freezer to be used in the branches of her dumplings and burger patty business.

loans.name: Doris Jhannet
