texts.es:
Doris es una joven natural del Departamento de La Libertad, ubicado en la costa norte peruana. Sus padres son separados, ella vive con su madre quien tiene un nuevo compromiso. Su padrastro trabaja de manera eventual como obrero de construcción civil, su madre para poder solventar los gastos familiares trabaja como niñera. Doris tiene 2 hermanos menores, quienes se encuentran estudiando.
Ella actualmente se encuentra estudiando el Tercer Ciclo de la Carrera de Administración Industrial, la cual le interesa mucho porque siente que le permitirá tener una vida muy organizada, también está segura que su carrera la beneficiará económicamente para así poder ayudar a su madre con la educación y crianza de sus hermanos menores.
Ella estuvo a punto de dejar de estudiar, porque la situación económica por la que se encuentra atravesando actualmente no le permiten continuar sus estudios, es por ello que está recurriendo al apoyo de KIVA para así no dejar de estudiar y convertirse en una excelente profesional.
Ella piensa que el apoyo que brinda KIVA a las personas es la mejor manera de poder cumplir con sus objetivos pues ellos (KIVA) la ayudan y contribuyen con la educación en el Perú.
texts.en: Doris is a young woman originally from the Department of La Libertad, located in the northern Peruvian coast. Her parents are separated. She lives with her mother who has a new relationship. Her stepfather works occasionally as a construction laborer, and her mother works as a nanny to help cover the family costs. Doris has 2 younger brothers, who are now studying. She is currently studying in the Third Cycle of the Industrial Management program, which she enjoys greatly. She feels that it will allow her to have a very organized life, and she is also sure that her career will benefit her economically thus allowing her to help her mother raise and educate her younger brothers. She was about to stop studying due to her current economic situation which does not permit her to continue her studies. Consequently, she is requesting the support from KIVA so that she does not stop studying and she can become an excellent professional. She thinks that the support provided to people by KIVA is the best way to accomplish their objectives, given that KIVA helps them and contributes to education in Peru.

loans.use: To continue studying Industrial Management and complete her studies successfully,  thus becoming an excellent professional.

loans.name: Drita

texts.en:
Drita, or ‘light' in English, is a married mother of three children ranging in age from 13 to 20. She is a villager who lives with her family in the northern part of the country. She works in a nearby fish factory while her husband and the oldest child have been receiving disability income.

Recently, the government demolished the front yard of her house in order to build a road, and as in so many other cases, they did not rebuild what they demolished or clean up the mess they left behind. Thus, Drita now has to build a fence again around the little house, so her neighbours’ animals do not wander in her territory.

To earn a living, she’s been pursuing the livestock business for some time now; having a dairy cow and selling about 3 kg of raw milk/day and a baby calf/year. All in all, she’s got 30 goats as well, from which she sells 20 baby goats a year during the month of May and also sells home made goat cheese from May to September.

loans.use: to rebuild a fence around her house that recently was destroyed by the local government who never fixed the mess they left behind.

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en:
Theogene is 29 years old. He is married with one child who is one year old. He has been farming for 11 years. Theogene will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers for maize, which he will sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for maize

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites, 46 years old, is married to a company driver with whom she has five children. Of her children, one is already married and with his own family while the rest of their children lives with Marites and are all studying. 

Marites says that supporting a big family such as hers is not easy. To help her husband, Marites worked before as a laundrywoman in their neighborhood. Earning from doing laundry, Marites made it a point to save a small portion of her savings. In 2012, with her savings, Marites ventured into business and sold poultry products. It was at the same time that she was invited by one of her customers to join SEED. Not knowing that there was this opportunity to avail a loan for micro-entrepreneurs such as her, Marites attended the orientation seminars and was accorded a first loan of PhP 8,000 eventually. The amount of her first loan was used by Marites to set up a general store that sells canned goods, cooking oil, and poultry products such as eggs and dressed chicken. 

With succeeding loan, Marites was able to buy 2 cavans of rice which she rolls out in a month. Seeing that rice vending gives her lucrative income, Marites on her 6th loan cycle now wants to avail a PhP 30,000 loan to buy an additional 10 cavans of rice and sacks of white and washed sugar for her to sell in general store. Marites says that aside from individual customers, she can also supply other small stores within her community of these items and in turn earn more. 

With business doing good and the extension of loan to her by SEED, Marites claims she was able to avail a house under a rent-to-own scheme. With this, Marites and her family is assured of security in housing. Marites dreams also of having her four other children finish their education.

loans.use: To buy additional cavans of rice, white sugar, and washed sugar which she sells in retail to customers in her store.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 48 years old and living alone. She has been separated from her husband since her child was still small. Sadly, too, her only child who’s barely 18 years old passed away due to kidney failure. 

Before, Teresita used to be employed as a factory worker. However, in 2003 she was forced by her mother to resign from her job in order for her to attend to her ill child personally. Her mother gave her PhP 5,000 for start-up capital to open a general store. With this Teresita was able to earn while being hands-on in the care of her child. In 2013, Teresita was invited by a neighbor who happens to be SEED's group leader in the area. From then, Teresita was able to avail a first loan in SEED and used it up to increase her stocks of canned goods. Because of the additional income, Teresita was able to support the medical needs of her child which was then still sick. However, with her child's health failing, Teresita is now left alone to tend to her own needs.

During her child's death, Teresita says she felt that she no longer needs to do business. However, she says that life should continue to go on. For one, she is no longer getting young and needs to prepare for the time that she will need to support her retirement. Also, she wanted to give support to her mother who has been her closest ally during the time that she was struggling with her child's ailment. Thus, Teresita saw it fit to continue running her store. 

On her 9th loan now, Teresita plans to buy cooking oil, rice, sugar and coffee in volumes. In turn, she will have this commodities repacked and sold in retail in her store. Repacking makes it more affordable for her customers to buy those items which they normally could not buy in volumes in the market or on grocery stores.  

Teresita says she is thankful that there are institutions like SEED who support small entrepreneurs like her. She says that with the loan being provided to her she was able to increase her savings. The savings has been proven useful not only to support her then sick child's medication but also addressed needs brought about by other emergencies. In the last typhoon that hit the country in October, Teresita was able to change the roof of her house which was destroyed by the typhoon.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, rice, sugar and coffee which she plans to sell on retail in her store.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna works hard to support her family's needs. Her husband works as a tricycle driver and earnings from this could hardly support their family's needs. To help her husband, in 2009 Myrna tried to invest in manufacturing home-made peanut butter. 

In 2010, Myrna got in touch with SEED through a promotion activity done by a staff in the area. She availed a loan and utilized it to  to put up a burger and snack stand for additional income of the family. Later on, as she feels her continuous success in her business, she thought of adding again items to sell in her store. She started selling cold soda drinks, fruit shakes, battered quail eggs and dumplings. 

To operate her business, Myrna goes to the market at 7:00 am everyday to buy ingredients for her burger and snack stand. For her peanut butter business, she does her marketing once a month to procure peanuts and the bottle containers to be used in the packaging of the finished products. With due diligence, Myrna was able to improve her business. She was able to invest in equipments such as stoves, gas ranges and a display shelf. She was also able to open another branch of her burger and snack stand and due to this was also able to provide employment to a neighbor who works for her as a store helper. 

Now Myrna is on her 11th cycle and wanted to avail a loan of PhP 30,000. Of which, she wanted to buy at least 50 kilos more of peanuts, cooking oil and sugar. These are necessary to increase her production of peanut butter. Aside from selling these in her snack stand, orders are also pouring in as much as some of her neighbors are beginning to market her peanut butter in exchange of commission sales. 

In the future, Myrna wants to add up another burger and snack stand. Myrna says she needs to work harder and earn more specially now that her daughter is on her junior year in college.

loans.use: To buy at least 50 kilos of peanuts, cooking oil and sugar to produce more peanut butter covering increased orders.

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.en:
Dilafruz is a hard-working and smart woman. She is married and has 3 children. She lives with her husband and 3 sons who are non-adultsyoung in a village. Dilafruz’s husband is a worker for hire and his income is not enough to provide the family with all the necessary things. Dilafruz tries to offer a better living standard for her children.

She started her animal husbandry business 6 months ago and she runs her business successfully. She plans to increase the working capital of her new business and in this way to improve it. She is asking for a loan of 1,000 TJS to buy cattle to increase the working capital of her new business. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy cattle and increase the working capital of her new business.

loans.name: Nurkhon

texts.en: Nurkhon is married and has 4 children. She has always wanted to provide her children with good education. Since her husband’s income is not enough to provide the family with a good quality of life, Nurkhon decided to start a new business in animal husbandry in order to generate an income she can contribute to her home’s finances. She completed the course "To Get Ahead" from a women's organization and learned new skills about business. Her children will help her with the business. She is confident that she will be a very successful businesswoman as she is hardworking and smart. She is asking for a loan of 2000 TJS to buy cattle for organizing her new business. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy cattle for organizing a new business

loans.name: Dolores

texts.es:
La socia es la Sra. Dolores; La socia pertenece al banco comunal SAN RAFAEL la socia sigue dedicándose al negocio de servicios de llamadas telefónicas, La socia  realiza llamadas nacionales y locales para los clientes que le solicitan, la socia se siente agradecida por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra  de un celular.
texts.en:
This communal bank member is Sra. Dolores.  She belongs to the San Rafael communal bank.  She still makes her living with a phone service business.  She offers national and local calls to the customers who request them.  Sra. Dolores feels grateful for the loan, and she promises to comply with her repayment plan.  She wants to continue working so she can keep helping her family. 
Sra. Dolores is requesting the loan to purchase a cell phone.

loans.use: to purchase a cell phone.

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en: Gulsara is a kind woman. She is married and has four children. Three of them are non-adults. Gulsara is going to start her own business and in this way improve their living conditions. Gulsara plans to start a business of animal husbandry as she lives in a village and has a good opportunity to develop this business. Gulsara will manage the business alone. She is asking for a loan of 1000 Somoni to buy cattle for increasing working capital. She awaits your mercy and in advance thanks you for support.

loans.use: to buy cattle for organizing a new business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married to Daniel and together they have been blessed with 5 children of ages between 27 and 18 years.Her spouse provides additional income for the family.

Mary is a farmer, a business she has done for the last 12 years, earning a monthly income of KES 30,000.

Mary has requested her third loan with VisionFund Kenya of KES 22,500 which she will use to buy farm inputs like organic fertilizers. She successfully repaid her previous loans.

With the anticipated profits, Mary will be able to repay her loan as well as improve the living standards of her family.

Her hope and dream for the future is to continually expand her business with future loan support from VisionFund Kenya.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs like organic fertilizers.

loans.name: Jean Bosco

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is a 28-year-old married man with two children, aged 1 month and 3 years old, who do not yet go to school. He has been farming for 5 years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers for maize to resell. The profits from the business will be used to pay his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for maize to resell.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice has a retail shop in Kapsabet town and has been running this business for 2 years. She is 21 years old, married and together with her spouse they have been blessed with 1 child. She also supports 2 members of her family.

She will use this loan to buy more stocks of maize and wheat flour, rice, salt and cooking oil to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her children.

This is her first loan term from VisionFund Kenya and in future she hopes to expand her business and be successful.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell.

loans.name: Haytham

texts.en:
Hetham is a 35-year-old, married man, living with his family in a miserable condition, in Taiz city, Yemen. Hetham is the sole breadwinner of the family and his income is very limited and insufficient to cover his family with the necessary expenses. His house lacks a lot of home appliances and furniture and most of them are very old. 

Hetham works hard to improve the living conditions of his family, but his income doesn't allow him to do that. For this reason, he applied for a loan of YER 500,000 from Al-Amal Microfinance Bank (AMB) in order to purchase some furniture for his house.

Hetham dreams to have his own business that will help him to improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase some furniture for his house.

loans.name: Annalita

texts.en:
Annalita maintains that responsibility is important in all undertakings. A single mother, she supports her daughter and the rest of the family needs through her business. 

Last May 2014, Annalita availed a loan of PhP 50,000 to buy additional inventory of rice, canned goods and liquefied petroleum gas according to her business plan for her general merchandise shop. On top of these, she was also able to procure bottled water in volumes which are highly demanded in her store. Annalita made it a point to repay her loan and knows that with a good credit standing, she have better chances of improving her business.

On her 5th loan cycle now, Annalita set up a new business venture selling out home-cooked viands. Sales from the new business increased with time. Annalita maintains that viand-selling is a hit owing to the location of her business which is situated in the commercial and industrial of the municipality.  With the initial capital invested in this business, Annalita was able to improve her income by 20% more. Likewise, Annalita is able to provide employment to four neighbors who work as helpers and cook in her businesses. With a new loan of PhP 80,000 Annalita will be able to buy pork, beef and chicken meat, fish and vegetables in volume to sustain and expand her eatery business. 

Annalita says that loan extended to her as a small micro-entrepreneur helps a lot specially that these loans have low interest and have no collateral. This is something that Annalita keeps in mind as she pursues payment of her loan on time. She is fully aware that as her business continues to grow, her financial situation also improves. This meant a better future for her child.

loans.use: To buy pork, beef and chicken meat, fish and vegetables in bulk for her eatery business.

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
At 52 years old, Winnie still works hard to support her family. Widowed and with 6 children, she sustains her family through her retail store which has been running since 2002. 

She became a member of SEED in 2011 and availed a first loan of PhP 5,000 which she used as additional capital to her store. With subsequent loans, Winnie was also able to set up a small burger stand in front of her house. The increased income enabled Winnie to buy more value added items for her store to include refilled tanks of liquefied petroleum gas. 

On her 8th loan now and with good repayment record on each previous loan cycles, Winnie plans to avail a PhP 25,000 loan. This time, she plans to invest on buying at least 5 more sacks of rice, bottled water and infant formula milk. These commodities are highly demanded in the community where she lives. Winnie maintains that if she is able to sell these items, her customers could save time and money relative to buying the city market or groceries.  

In the future, Winnie wanted to grow her general store into a general merchandise. She dreams of passing on this business to her children some day.

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, bottled water, infant formula milk which are highly demanded in her community.

loans.name: Norhata

texts.en:
Norhata, a Muslim, 42 years old is married and have 8 children. 

In order to help her husband and family to have an increased income, Norhata opened a shop selling mobile phone accessories in 2010. During the same year, Norhata encountered SEED through another Muslim neighbor who also benefits from SEED's programs and services. Norhata was happy to find an institution that not only provides capital for business to Muslims like her (where there are only a few microfinance institutions working with Muslims in the city where she lives) but more importantly provides important services to include business and social development training. Seeing the benefits, Norhata completed the membership process and availed a loan of PhP 10,000. The money she acquired was invested by Norhata on buying additional mobile phone accessories. With diligence and good repayment record, Norhata was able to avail reloans which she have used in the past to add more items to her shop including portable stereos and speakers. Also, Norhata was able to provide employment to one neighbor who assists her in manning her mobile phone accessories shop. 

On her 5th loan cycle now, Norhata is planning to avail a PhP 25,000 loan to invest in equipments which will enable the repairs of mobile phones and other electronic gadgets such as tablets. Norhata claims that with this service, her business will be a one-stop shop for all those looking for affordable electronic items and repairs of the same. With this, she will also be able to employ another neighbor to do the repairs.

loans.use: To buy equipments enabling repairs of mobile phone and other electronic gadgets.

loans.name: Rozigul

texts.en:
Rozigul is 49 years old, married, and has three children. Her husband is a construction worker. She is a saleswoman, working at the central market of the Jilikul district where she has a retail outlet. She sells food products such as cookies, candies, and other sweets, which she has been doing for five years.  Her daughters assist Rozigul in her business.
 
Rozigul requested a loan, which she will use to purchase a varied assortment of food products to develop her trade.

loans.use: to purchase an assortment of food products

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita is a 50-year-old married woman from Ajuy, Iloilo. She has four dependents. Amelita works with her husband in their fishing business. This has been the source of their income for more than  20 years now. 

Amelita is asking to take out a loan to buy fishing materials like nets, hooks, lead weights and floaters and a new boat engine. This loan will help Amelita and her husband in improving their catch thus giving them more fish to sell in the market. Amelita dreams of making their fishing business a success and stable. Moreover, she wants to save money for her children’s schooling.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like nets, hooks, lead weights and floaters and a new boat engine

loans.name: Ramiro

texts.es: Ramiro esta casado y tiene tres hijas que estan estudiando en colegio Ramiro es abogado independiente y quiere equipar su oficina, para eso el cliente pide un prestamo para comprar una computadora, este equipo le sera de mucha importancia  para presentar informes sobre los casos que atiende y las defensas que realiza Ramiro quiere darles mas comodidades a sus hijas, meterlas en un mejor colegio y trasladarse pues actualmente la familia vive en un departamento pequeño y pagan un alquiler, Ramiro espera que puedan ayudarlo
texts.en:
Ramiro is married and has three daughters who are all in school. He is a self employed attorney and wants to equip his office. In order to do this, this borrower is requesting a loan to buy a computer. This equipment will be essential for Ramiro to write reports about his cases and prepare a defense for his clients. 

Ramiro wants to give his daughters a more comfortable life by enrolling them in a better school and moving, since he and his family are currently living in a small rented apartment. He hopes to get some help in order to achieve all of this.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Rowayda

texts.en:
Rowayda is a 18-year-old single lady from Jabalia City. She lives with her family in a small, simple house. Her father works as an employee in the public sector where he gets a low income. This is the only source of income for the family. Rowayda is a student in a local university where she studies health management.

She wants to complete her studies and find a job in the future.

Rowayda took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her to buy a new laptop for her studies. By taking this loan, Rowayda will be able to do her homework and write her reports easily.

Rowayda appears in the photo

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for her studies.

loans.name: Segundina

texts.en:
Segundina does farming. She toils the land and grows rice.  To augment her income, she also engages in buying and selling root crops. She is widowed woman with four grown children, residing in the town of Dulag, Leyte.  She has been engaged in that kind of business for 15 years. 

Segundina is asking for a loan to purchase assorted root crops to sell and fertilizers. She will be purchasing a variety of root crops to sell. These will be essential for improving her current sources of income. The harvest will improve and slowly increase her earnings. In the future, Segundina would like to expand both sources of her income to definitely change her livelihood status.

loans.use: to purchase assorted root crops to sell and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for educational equipment and preparation of teaching materials for her medical clown business

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne is 27 years old, married and together with her spouse they have been blessed with two children. She sells clothes and shoes and has been running her business for two years. She also supports four members of her family

She plans to use this loan to buy more clothes and shoes to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

This is her first loan term from VisionFund Kenya and her future hopes are to open another boutique shop and be successful.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Vide

texts.en:
Vide is requesting this loan to buy one electrical appliance, a piece of furniture and  five piglets.

Vide is 37 years old and has three young children. They moved two years ago and had previously lived  in the most rural part of the country where roads were unpaved  and electricity was limited. They currently live in an in-law's house for free. Vide is trying to build a life here and she wants to buy five piglets  to establish a livestock business. Her husband is  a mechanic in a nearby auto service shop. Vide hopes that lenders will understand her situation, she promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: to purchase five piglets, furniture and a home appliance.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is 64 years old. She is a widow with eight children and lives in Sindangan, Philippines. Emma is managing her fishing business and owns fish cages as well. She earns a good income each month doing this type of work, supporting the needs of her big family, especially her children's education until they graduated and got their own jobs. 

She has requested a loan  to purchase 100 liters of diesel gasoline, paints and epoxy, and pay for an engine repair. In the future, Emma hopes to buy another fishing boat to improve and expand her fishing business.

loans.use: to purchase 100 liters diesel gasoline, paints and epoxy, and pay for an engine repair

loans.name: Yvey

texts.es:
Yvey es una joven natural del Distrito de Pachacamac que vive junto a su madre y su hermano menor. Su madre para sacar adelante a sus hijos está trabajando como operaria de producción. Su padre por el tipo de trabajo que realiza, no vive con ellos. Él trabaja como obrero de construcción de manera eventual, en diferentes partes del Perú, según el tipo de obra.
Ella para poder apoyar a su madre también está trabajando en un restaurante, pero entre el horario de trabajo y sus estudios, se le dificulta continuar con su Carrera, es por ello que recurre a KIVA para solicitar el apoyo que necesita y así culminar sus estudios de manera satisfactoria. Si no hubiera contado con el apoyo de KIVA, tendría que dejarla y es algo que no le gustaría porque le encanta su carrera.
Ella está estudiando el Tercer Ciclo de Administración Industrial, la cual le interesa mucho porque siente que le permitirá desarrollarse más y a la vez ayudaría a su familia a darle una vida mejor.
Ella se siente muy agradecida por el apoyo que KIVA le está brindando porque gracias a ellos, podrá culminar su carrera que tanto le gusta y destacarse como una excelente profesional.
texts.en:
Yvey is a young woman from the district of Pachacamac who lives with her mother and younger brother. Her mother provides for them by working as a production operative. Her father doesn't live with them due to the type of work he does. He is a seasonal construction worker and travels to different areas in Peru depending on the type of job.

Yvey is also working at a restaurant in order to help her mother, but between her work schedule and her studies it is hard for her to earn her degree. That is why she has come to Kiva to request the support she needs in order to finish school successfully. If she didn't have Kiva's support she would have to drop out and she wouldn't like that because she loves her classes. She is in her third year of Industrial Management, and she is very interested in this field because she thinks it will help her make further progress and at the same time help her family have a better life.

She is very grateful for the support Kiva offers because thanks to its lenders she will be able to earn her degree. She really enjoys school and wants to excel professionally.

loans.use: to cover her education costs.

loans.name: Inocenta

texts.en: Inocenta is 70 years old and lives in Punta, Panaon, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is married with two adult children. Inocenta earns her living from her sari-sari store (small convenience store). She’s been engaged in this business for almost five years. She earns approximately 1,000 PHP each month doing this type of business activity, which is very helpful in meeting her family needs. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing construction materials for a house repair. Inocenta has been a member of PMPC for nine years. In the future, Inocenta hopes to expand her sari-sari store business.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for a house repair

loans.name: Tahal

texts.en:
Mr Tahal lives in East Kalimantan on the enormous island of Borneo. Even though it rains a lot in Borneo and most of the island is covered by ever green plantations and rainforests, it is hard to get drinking water. That is why he started looking for a filter. As he says:

“ I started selling in 2010, I was looking for a water filter that makes water ready to drink, and that is of course, is cheap and easy to use. I browsed internet, that is how I started to know Nazava Water Filters.  I ordered one filter from another reseller and started selling them. 
At first we were hesitant to consume water that has been filtered by a Nazava Water filter but to eliminate any doubt, we tested water that was filtered Nazava. We were really surprised and amazed after knowing the results of the lab that showed that the water was clean and germ free. I have been using Nazava Water Filters for 4 years now.”

Nazava Water Filters costs less than 20 USD and provide and enable families to filter their well tap and rain water so it becomes safe to drink. Shipping water filters to Kalimantan is expensive, especially when you ship in small amounts. Mr Tahal wants to use the loan to ship 150 filter in one time which means he can significantly save on shipping costs.  At the same time it will help him deliver safe drinking water to 750 people.

loans.use: To provide inhabitants of East Borneo with clean drinking water

loans.name: Serah

texts.en:
Serah, 52 years of age, is a farmer in Kapsabet town and has been in the farming business for five years. She is married and together with her spouse they have been blessed with three children. She also supports seven members in her family.

She has requested her first loan from VisionFund Kenya which she will use to buy farm inputs like fertilizer and seeds for planting on her farm. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

Her future hopes are to expand her business and improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs for use in farming.

loans.name: Richer

texts.en:
Richer is 31 years old and lives in Butuay, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental in the Philippines. He is single with one child. Richer is a security guard and earns approximately 8,000 PHP each month doing this type of work. 

He has requested a loan to purchase construction materials for house renovation and extension. Richer has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) for four years. In the future, Richer hopes to open a sari-sari store business together with his live-in partner.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for house renovation and extension

loans.name: Wahyu

texts.en:
Wahyu sells Nazava Water Filters in central Java, the most populous island of Indonesia. Nazava Water Filters turn dirty well, tap and rain water into safe drinking water without the need for boiling.  This is Wahyu’s second loan, he considered his first loan a success:
“Nazava Water Filters in Yogyakarta is growing every day. We have tried various ways to promote Nazava Products namely: radio advertisement and presentations at women groups. We hope Nazava will be the water filter leader in Yogyakarta."
Wahyu now places a second order. To further expand his business he has two strategies: 1) Build a network of agents. Sell water filters on consignment which will allow poorer households to buy them as well. 
This loan will enable Mr Wahyu to buy around 150 water filters that can deliver truly safe drinking water to 600 people.

loans.use: to buy around 150 water filters that can deliver truly safe drinking water to 600 people.

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia lives in a community in the Department of Intibucá Honduras. She is dedicated to Agriculture (coffee). Age 42 years; she is married and has two children. It is clear that Emilia works hard to maintain her family and at night, after a hard day of work, the conditions in the house are not very good due to the lack of electricity. She hopes that with the solar energy system, her children will be able to continue studying and improve the living conditions.
Emilia is requesting a loan to purchase a complete solar electric system from SOLUZ Honduras, that will permit to have a better lighting, charge her cell phones, and saving in traditional energy expenditure.

loans.use: to purchase a solar home system that will allow her to reduce spending in kerosene, candles, and improve the home lighting.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay laborers to maintain and harvest crops.

loans.name: Friendship Mae

texts.en:
Friendship Mae is 18 years old and is the first of two children in the family. Her mother, Michelle, supports the family through her fruit vending business in the Philippines.

Friendship Mae is studying Bachelor of Science in Accountancy and is currently in the 3rd of this 4-year course. Friendship Mae is borrowing 12,000 to pay for tuition fees of the 2nd semester of school year 2014-2015. Friendship Mae plans to graduate and be gainfully employed in the future.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: Huyen

texts.en:
Huyen is a 46-year-old divorced woman. She lives with one child in Ho Chi Minh City. For 20 years, she has been running a general store and selling lottery tickets.

Huyen would like a loan to purchase a greater quantity and variety of basic products such as snack foods and confectionery to sell from her store. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional customers. 

She also hopes that through her loan, she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity and variety of basic products to sell in her general store

loans.name: Belenda

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Belenda works hard to support her family.

She has a business selling fish in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling food. Belenda is borrowing PHP 6,000 through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell through her business.

Belenda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: So's Group

texts.en:
So is 44 years old and lives with his two children and wife. So has been running a business of parking vehicles to earn an income to support his family. So is the Group Leader of a three-member loan group that lives in Ho Chi Minh City. In the picture, he is on the left side wearing a plain white shirt. Each of the other group members are requesting loans to fund income-generating activities.

So is requesting a loan to purchase a bicycle for his family. He hopes this will help his children to travel to school and enable him to give his full attention to his business. He also hopes that through his loan, he will be able to increase his income and save money for any future difficulties facing his family.

loans.use: to purchase a bicycle for transportation for his family

loans.name: Le

texts.en:
Le is 55 years old and single. She lives with her family in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City. She operates a general store, which she has been doing for 15 years.  

Le requested a loan, which she will use to expand her business by buying larger quantities and varieties of different products, such as confectionery, cooking oil, and fish sauce, to sell to her customers. She hopes that her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase products, such as confectionery, cooking oil, and fish sauce to sell

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena and her husband live in Stepanavan town. Her husband drives a taxi, and Yelena herself is involved in cattle breeding. She keeps a livestock of three cows, three calves, and one pig. She gets dairy products from the livestock, and sells it locally. 

Because agricultural income is very important for this couple to meet their daily needs, Yelena has applied for this loan to enlarge her farm. She asks lenders to support her with purchasing two more cows and forage for feeding the cattle. 

Yelena hopes that this loan will help her to enlarge the production of dairy products, and she will be able to get more money for living.

loans.use: to pay for two more cows and forage for feeding the cattle

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Yen, 65, is single. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. She earns an income running a generel store in front of her house. 

Yen started this business five years ago. She sells a variety of different sauces, sugar, soft drinks, and other household items to people in her community. She is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying a larger quantity of food products and household items to sell and better satisfy her customers.

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of food products and household items for resale

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose, pictured above, has been a farmer for 20 years, and is now proud to represent her group of 13 farmers in Kakamega South District. She is 48 years old, married, and has six children.

Rose likes to think of herself as a very hardworking individual. She has been working alongside One Acre Fund since 2012 and decided to represent her group because she wanted to help more farmers. She says that being part of the One Acre Fund community has meant that she has been able to save more money. Rose plans to use the profits from this coming season to buy a cow.

In total, Rose’s Group will receive inputs to cultivate 6.75 acres of land. Given that some members of the group will also be purchasing a solar light, with this loan, the group will also receive a total of three solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to improve harvests of maize.

loans.name: Chikondi Group

texts.en:
Marita appreciates Kiva for the previous loan that she was granted. She used the loan to expand and divert her business from a general store to a shop were she sells first hand clothes.  She opted for this business since it is highly demanded in her area. The profits from her previous loan have also helped her to reduce her family’s level of poverty, as she is now able to provide her children with food three times a day, and she is also able to pay their medical bills.

She is requesting another loan in order to expand her business further by purchasing more clothes. This will assist her to generate more profits. Thereby, fully alleviating her family’s level of poverty.

loans.use: to buy first hand clothes.

loans.name: Rositas De Huancollo Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ROSITAS DE HUANCOLLO” iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Copacabana, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Pastora es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de leche, venta de queso, venta de chompas tejidas.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Pastora es integrante, ella indica que es el primer año que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de un promotor de la institución que fue a visitarle a su domicilio. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio lechería; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió hace varios años, iniciando con un pequeño capital, el cual fue incrementando poco a poco.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de vaca) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de su comunidad y posteriormente a la crianza, comercializará sus productos en las ferias comunales. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es casada y tiene once hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The communal bank "ROSITAS DE HUANCOLLO" will begin its first cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Copacabana regional hub. The group consists of eight members and is led by a board of directors, where Pastora serves as the chairwoman. 

The members of the communal bank carry on various businesses, which include selling milk, selling cheese, and selling knitted "chompas" (sweaters).

The loan that the group will take out will benefit the owners of small microbusinesses, including Pastora. She says that this is her first year with Pro Mujer and that she became a member at the invitation of an outreach officer from the institution who went to visit her at her home. Currently, she runs a dairy business. She mentions that she started this business many years ago with a small capital, which she gradually increased.

The loan that she will take out now is to increase her capital by purchasing a cow, which she will acquire from the wholesale vendors from her community, and, after rearing the animal, she will sell her dairy products at the community fairs. This line of work allows her to generate the means to support her family financially, as she is married and has 11 children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes the training offered by the institution.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Dilbarjon

texts.en:
Dilbarjon is married and has 3 children and  lives with her family in Tajikistan.

Dilbarjon is going to raise livestock to earn an income and has some experience in this field because  she helped her parents feed cattle when she was a child. 

Dilbarjon requests 15,000 TJS to buy cattle and start a new business. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy cattle to start a  new business.

loans.name: Pablo

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal SAN RAFAEL, él banco está ubicado en el departamento de Cusco.
El socio continua  con el negocio de carpintería, el socio se siente agradecido por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas, él socio continua elaborando elabora muebles, mesas, camas entre otros, él socio desea que su negocio prospere, siendo de esta manera que el socio saca adelante a su familia.
El socio solicita el crédito para la compra de madera.
texts.en: This borrower belongs to the communal bank San Rafael, which is located in the department of Cusco. He is still working as a carpenter and is grateful for his previous loan. He promises to comply with his payment terms. This borrower continues to make furniture like tables, beds, and other items. He wants his business to prosper, since it is his means to provide for his family. He will use this loan to buy more wood.

loans.use: to buy wood.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a married woman with three kids, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Irene operates a grocery stall selling vegetables, She sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a challenge of high costs of transportation to her place of operation.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase green vegetables, 2 crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a motorcycle transport business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, 2 crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale

loans.name: Remy

texts.en:
Remy is 36 years old and has been solely rearing her two children, aged 14 and 9, after she was separated from her husband. To make ends meet, Remy opened a small general store in their house and this has been the source of her family's income until now. 

After attending the orientation seminar of SEED, Remy availed a first loan amounting to PhP 6,000 which she used as additional capital for her store. As her business began earning well, and with the infusion of the loan, Remy added up other businesses to include a burger stand. Likewise, Remy made it a point that at the end of the day with each earning she makes, she is able to set up an amount to prepare her weekly payment for her loan and put also a portion to her savings. 

On her 12th loan cycle now, Remy wants to avail PhP 30,000 which she intends to buy toys, slippers, and frozen meat products for her store. Remy notes that these items are highly demanded with the holiday season. Remy recounts that as early as October she had been receiving orders from her neighbors on those items which they intend to buy for themselves, their children or be made as gifts. Remy saw this as an opportunity to increase her income further.

With hard work, and alone at that matter, Remy was able to sustain the needs of her family. Not only that, she was also able to buy a television set and an electric fan which made her children enjoy more convenience. In the future, Remy wants to go strong with the selling of frozen meat products and wants to avail a freezer for that.

loans.use: To buy toys, slippers and frozen meat products which are highly sellable during the holidays.

loans.name: Galilaya Twimukye Group

texts.en:
Filimon is a  hard working 30-year-old married man with four children who are 6, 5, 3 and 1 years old. He resides with his family in Galilaya Mpefu.

He has been a produce dealer  since 2009 to earn a living for his family and requests 500,000 UGX to buy corn and millet from farmers which he will store  in anticipation of prices increases in Feb. when he believes he will make more profit. 

His dream is to build his family a descent house. His major challenges include lack of capital and fluctuating prices which negatively affect his business. He hopes he will soon over come these challenges if he keeps getting financial assistance.

loans.use: to buy corn and millet.

loans.name: Melecia

texts.en:
Melecia, 56 years old, is hardworking person and uses her skills in cooking native delicacies to support her family. Each morning, she wakes up at 3:00 a.m. to prepare and cook native delicacies which she would sell the whole day. Aside from native delicacies, Melecia also sells breakfast and snack items in her neighborhood. 

In 2010, Melecia attended SEED's orientation and was able to avail a first loan which she used as additional capital to her native delicacies business. With diligence in savings and repayment, Melecia was able to sustain her business and eventually was able to provide income to 3 neighbors who sells her delicacies on a commission basis. 

With the holiday season, her orders and the demand for native delicacies have tripled. It is Filipino custom to serve or give as gifts native delicacies such as "biko" (rice cake), "halayang ube" (jammed purple yam) and "maja blanca" (coconut pudding). There were also orders of different pansit (noodles) dishes. Thus, on her 9th loan now, Melecia wants to avail a PhP 30,000 loan to buy glutinous rice, coconut, sugar and yams in volume to meet the orders she have for the holidays. Melecia says that from a daily income of PhP 500, with the additional fund she will be able to earn as much as PhP 1,500 per day. 

In the future, Melecia wants to be able to set-up a catering business.

loans.use: To buy glutinous rice, coconut, sugar, yams in volumes for holiday orders of native delicacies.

loans.name: Vitore

texts.en:
Vitore is 40 years old and has three children who are 17, 10 and 8 years old. She has earned her living raising livestock and she has two dairy cows, one calf, and six pigs. She sells about 50 kg of homemade cheese, two calves and equal number of piglets a year. Her husband works as a prison guardian in a nearby prison. 

Vitore is seeking your understanding because she’s hasn’t paid the electricity bill  from year 2007-2011. This happened almost to everyone in the rural due to the fact the previous electricity company that was the largest and the only in the country, failed. The current company who bought the previous one is setting up strict operational rules spreading even to the farthest areas of the country. All those citizens who failed to pay electricity obligations must pay immediately.

loans.use: to pay for the accumulated electricity bills.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie is 41 years old, married and with 2 children who are both studying. Her husband, works as a councilor in the Barangay (the smallest political and governing unit in the country) and earns only a monthly allowance which could hardly suffice for their needs if they will only rely on this.

Prior to this, Rosie and her husband worked in a factory. In 2004, Rosie and her husband decided to resign and manage their own business. With the separation pay that they had after the resignation, Rosie opened a small "sari-sari" (general) store within their house premises. Rosie found it good that she and her husband is able to earn from the business and at the same time personally look after their children at home. 

However, with the growing needs of their family, Rosie's husband thought of going on fishing as their residence is located within the sea-strip of Cavite. It was at this time in 2012 that Rosie encountered SEED which at that time was performing an outreach program in their community in time for Christmas. In the beginning of 2013, Rosie looked for SEED's office and inquired on how to become a member. From there, Rosie was able to avail a first loan of PhP 10,000 which she used to buy a second hand motor for a fishing boat that she and her husband has earlier acquired. 

The boat became operational and Rosie's husband was able to augment their income with fishing. With increased income, Rosie was able to roll out her capital further on her sari-sari store which enabled her to buy prime commodities such as rice. The sari-sari store also served as income buffer when Rosie's husband could not go out on the seas to fish specially, when there is a typhoon.  On the other hand, the fishing business of her husband also went well. To date they are able to provide income to 8 neighbors who help them in fishing wherein 2 are net maintenance weavers and 6 fishermen. 

However, the second hand motor they have bought is already failing. As such, on her 5th loan now, Rosie wants to buy a new motor for their fishing boat. To be able to buy this, Rosie would need at least PhP 30,000. Rosie hopes that the loan will be granted in as much as getting the fishing boat in top shape could improve not only their family's income but also the income of the 8 other neighbors who benefit from their business.

loans.use: To buy a new motor for their fishing boat that support their family's income and 8 other neighbors.

loans.name: Juvitha

texts.en:
Juvitha is 42 years of age and lives in Caputol, Aloran, Philippines. She is a widow with four adult-aged children, Juvitha is engaged in the retail business; she buys merchandise in bulk for retailing. She has had this business for eight years now.

Juvitha requested a loan to pay for her pawned cocoland in her desire to do farming activities. The income from her business will pay off the loan she requested from PMPC. She has been a member of PMPC for two years already. In the future, Juvitha hopes to have a good standard of living with her family and adequate income out of her business.

loans.use: to pay for her pawned cocoland in her desire to do farming activities

loans.name: Dilnoza

texts.en:
Dilnoza was born in 1966. She is a careful mother of two children. She is married and she lives with her family in the northern part of Tajikistan. 

Dilnoza has her own business deal. For more than two years, she has been busy buying and selling women's and children's clothes in a local market. She has a store in a local market. She develops the business, little by little. 

Dilnoza is asking for a loan of TJS 2,500 (somoni) to increase her working capital and buy clothes. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy women's and children's clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a new taxi to run the transportation service.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa is from Dolipos Alto, Oroquieta City. She and her husband have land for rice and have earned a living doing farming activities ever since they got married.

Recently, Luisa requested a loan to purchase a carabao (water buffalo) to plough and harrow their wetland with the hope of yielding more harvest.

Luisa deeply wishes to save enough for their needs and live a happy and healthy life with her family.

loans.use: to purchase carabao (water buffalo) to plough and harrow wetland.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a businesswoman who earns income through her sari-sari store business. She is a full-fledged member of PMPC and enjoys the benefits of insurance and financial assistance.

Recently, she applied for a loan to purchase bags of cement and hollow blocks. She is on her way to renovating her house. She wishes to live comfortably with her family.

loans.use: to purchase bags of cement and hollow blocks

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: for paying PV systems installed in their houses.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: for paying PV systems installed in their houses.

loans.name: Dieneba's Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe a été mis en place le 18 Octobre 2012 et le banc villageois porte le nom du village qui l’abrite. Il regroupe en son sein des femmes unies par des liens de solidarité et de parenté. En plus du commerce les femmes pratiquent l’aviculture et l’agriculture.

Madame Diénaba (debout à l’extrême  gauche avec une main levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants dont 02 garçons et 03 filles. C’est une femme très active dans la vie du banc villageois, son activité s’inscrit dans la vente de denrées alimentaires et condiments qu’elle achète  au marché de la commune pour la revente au détail dans son village: sucre, ognon, poivres, huile de palme, thé vert,  et bouillons culinaires …. Elle jouit d’une bonne expérience dans ce domaine.

Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte renouveler son stock par l’achat d’un sac de sucre, un bidon d’huile de palme de 20 litres, 05 paquets de bouillions, du thé vert et autres.

Les bénéfices servent à aider son mari dans les charges de la famille ainsi qu’a assurer une meilleure scolarité aux enfants.
texts.en:
This group was established 18 October 2012 and is made up of women, who are united and share family ties and solidarity. 

In addition to commerce, the women work in poultry farming and agriculture. Dienaba (who is standing on the far left with her hand raised [in the photo]), is the featured borrower of the group. She is married and a mother of five children, of whom two are boys and three are girls. 

Dienaba is very active, and she works selling foodstuffs and condiments, which she buys at a market in the area. She makes her sales at retail in her village: sugar, onions, peppers, palm oil, tea, and broth cubes. She has had a good experience with this work.

With this new loan, she plans to renew her stock by buying a sac of sugar, a 20-liter drum of palm oil, five packets of broth cubes, green tea, and other goods. Earnings will serve to help her husband with the family expenses, especially to ensure a better education for her children.

loans.use: to restock by buying a sac of sugar, a 20-liter drum of palm oil, five packets of broth cubes, green tea, and other goods

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
Eufemia appears on her photo in front of one of the food stalls she rents out to food vendors. She is thankful that she was granted a PHP 10,000 PHP loan, which she used for the repair and maintenance of her stalls. She has different food stalls for rent and an apartment as well. She is glad that her rental income helps support her family and meet their daily basic needs.

She would like now to apply for a PHP 30,000 loan, which she will use to pay for the labor and materials to renovate her apartment for rent and partly for her food stalls as well. She needs to improve her apartment to make it more safe and attractive. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to her. Her rental income helps a lot in providing for her daily living expenses. 

Eufemia dreams of adding another door to her apartment. She desires to have her own house and prays for long life and good health. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship group* to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for renovations to her rental apartment and food stalls for rent.

loans.name: Theophile

texts.en:
Theophile is a 40-year-old married man with 6 children aged between the ages of 1 and 16; five attend school. He has farmed for  4 years and requests a loan  to buy fertilizer for maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for his children.


The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a 61-year-old married who has two children who are 13 and 11 years old.  She has sold second-hand clothing for eight years and earns a monthly income of 16,800 KES which she uses to support her family.

She has applied for her first loan of KES. 7,000 from Vision Fund Kenya and intends to use the  loan to buy an energy saving jiko (a biomass cook stove that burns firewood and crop waste)  for use in her family. 

Esther hopes to grow her business and be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy an energy saving jiko stove.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a  29-year-old married man with a one-year-old child. He has farmed for 11 years. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer for maize and beans. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for his children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to  connect a radio to the SSHS in order to mitigate her isolation, as well as use the four hours of electrical lighting for cooking and having dinner more easily.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: for paying to have PV systems installed in their houses.

loans.name: Kafunda Group

texts.fr: Comme dans les habitudes du milieu et de leur époque, Remix a été initié à la culture du café par ses parents à l'âge de 13 ans afin de lui permettre de se prendre en charge et  d'une certaine façon de participer aux besoins sociaux de la population insulaire. Cette activité a cependant des difficultés par rapport aux maladies qui attaquent les plantes et l'incertitude des marchés. Toutefois, il aspire à un avenir meilleur pour sa famille et à rajeunir sa plantation. Président du groupe KAFUNDA, Remix porte un chapeau et une jacquette noire sur la photo.
texts.en:
As is the custom in that area and at that time, Remix was taught to grow coffee by his parents at the age of 13 so as to permit him to earn his living and, in a way, to participate in the social needs of this isolated population. 

This business has its difficulties, however, from the point of view of the illnesses that attack the plants and insecurity as to markets. In any case, Remix aspires to a better future for his family and to renew his plantation. The president of the group called Kafunda, Remix is wearing a cap and a black jacket in the photo.

loans.use: to maintain his fields and pay laborers for the harvest

loans.name: Leus

texts.en:
Leus is grateful that she was granted a 50,000 PHP loan, which she used to purchase various grocery items and products needed in her general store. She is glad that through her earnings she is able to send her children to school and meet their daily living expenses. 

She would now like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan, which she will use to buy large quantities of grocery items like rice, coffee, soda and rice noodles, which she sells at retail. She knows that having more items in her store will yield more sales and thus increase her earnings. Her general store is a stable source of income to sustain her family's basic needs and pay for the education of her children. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to her. 

Leus dreams to expand into a bigger grocery store and aims to give her children the best education possible for them to have a better future. Every week, she meets up with her fellowship group* to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

*All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital  and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages to sell.

loans.name: Cliff

texts.en:
Cliff, a youthful 28-year-old farmer from Mosobeti, a remote village in the Nyamira area of Kenya, is elegant and admirable in spirit and effort. He is a role model, a mentor and an inspiration to many young farmers in his village because of his resilience, despite personal challenges, and his passion to support his one child as a primary caregiver. 

The living conditions in the Nyamira area are very tough, and you need to have tough skin in order to survive. Cliff has always shown the resilience to beat all odds. Because of the hardcore poverty in his village, Cliff started practicing mixed farming and has been doing it for the past 10 years. Cliff's sources of income are vegetables, milk, tea and egg selling; these products are very perishable and require timely delivery to the market, and one problem that he faces is delivering to the market on time. 

The Nyamira area has a poor road network and poor feeder roads that really hamper timely delivery of products to the market; that is why Cliff is kindly seeking a loan to buy a motorbike. With the motorbike he will deliver products to the market on time and reap more profits because the products will still be fresh. 

Cliff is very determined to succeed and because he is very disciplined with finances, he plans that through accumulated profits, he will be able to provide a secure future for himself and also for his grandchildren to come. Cliff's dream is to provide a secure future for his siblings through paying tuition fees for them. Through your loan, you will help him realize his dream.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to deliver products to the market.

loans.name: Hanh

texts.en:
Hanh is 51 years old and single. She lives with her family in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City. She  earns income through selling salt. 

She started her business ten years ago. She intends to take a loan to gradually expand her business by buying a larger quantity of unprocessed salt to process and sell to her customers. 

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of unprocessed salt to process and sell

loans.name: Sulait

texts.en: Sulait is a thirty-seven-year old married man with four children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. He has a butcher shop and this is his major source of income. He also has a cocoa garden.  Sulait is a hardworking man who looks after his family very well. He pays school fees for all his children. His challenge is limited capital. He is requesting a loan to buy goats for butchering.

loans.use: to buy goats for his butcher shop

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Hello, wonderful Kiva lenders! The dairy business is an important source of income to small-scale farmers in Kenya. Juhudi Kilimo is partnering with Kiva to provide financial and technical solutions to poor farmers such as Julius, a father of four children in the Molo area of Kenya. Julius has been a mixed farmer for the past six years, and his primary sources of income have been milk, eggs and food crops.He also has a side business (motorcycle business).

 The Molo area has a cool climate, but sometimes experiences long dry spells, and this accounts for major crop failures which can lead to starvation. Julius is seeking a loan to purchase a high quality dairy cow. Easy availability of feed and fodder all year round makes dairy farming an ideal choice of investment in this region. Through the loan, Julius will be able to fully satisfy the demand for milk in his village and through increased income; he will be able to improve his living conditions. 

This loan will be very important because it will not only improve Julius’s life, but also, he will be able to get manure, which will be used on his farm and improve productivity. Through Juhudi Kilimo, Julius has been trained on how to save money, and he plans to use the extra income to expand his business and is planning to buy another dairy cow. All Julius is waiting for is your kindness.

loans.use: To buy a quality dairy cow.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard has a small farm in the heartland of Nyabite, a remote village in the Nyamira area of Kenya. He is a married man  blessed with five children. Richard has  farmed for twelve years. His primary income sources are from selling milk, eggs, and working other personal businesses. 

The land in the Nyamira area is characterized by a rolling topography, not permitting the best cultivation practices to be followed. The only farming business that thrives is poultry farming. Richard seeks a loan to purchase poultry. There is so much growth opportunity in the poultry business in Kenya. The demand for poultry products is always high, especially during the festive seasons. Richard has always had chickens but only recently has moved from a subsistence basis to a commercial one. 

He dreams of expanding the business but he is constrained financially. He will use the loan to purchase fowl. He will then be in a position to produce many eggs and meat to sell in the local market. The income generated from the sale of the poultry products will help Richard to afford his children’s educational expenses.

Support a humble farmer and help him to get ahead with a loan!

loans.use: to buy poultry.

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Huong is requesting a new loan to buy a range of new products, such as cooking oil, sugars and beverages, to restock her general store. This purchase will help her to better meet the needs of her customers. Her previous loan enabled her to improve her business and offer her customers a greater variety of products. She hopes that her new loan will assist her to increase the size of her store and increase sales, and will also help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a range of new products, such as cooking oil, sugars and beverages, to restock her general store.

loans.name: Duc

texts.en: Duc is requesting a new loan to buy and process auto tires for resale. His previous loan enabled him to improve his business and sales. He hopes that his new loan will assist him in increasing the size of his business and increasing his income, and will also help him to improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy and process auto tires for selling

loans.name: Danis Danith

texts.es:
Denis es una bella, carismática, sonriente, servicial, emprendedora mujer de 33 años de edad, madre soltera de una pequeña de 8 años de edad, las necesidades económicas presente en su hogar  y la falta de oportunidades de empleo la llevaron a tomar la necesidad de acelerar un proyecto que tenía desde tiempo atrás que era Iniciar su propia empresa, como es una mujer inteligente vio que en su sector hace falta una papelería, y una fotocopiadora y es este estudio que la lleva a solicitar un crédito para iniciar su propio negocio de papelería comprando surtido para la temporada escolar, también comprara una maquina fotocopiadora.
Sus sueños con su nuevo proyecto es poder mantenerlo en el tiempo, lograr un punto de equilibro rápidamente y proyectar su negocio para que este le pueda dar una casa propia para vivir felizmente junto con su hija.
texts.en:
Denis is a beautiful, charismatic, smiling, helpful, enterprising 33 year old woman. A single mother to an 8 year old girl, the economic demands of her home and the lack of job opportunities have led her to make the decision to accelerate a project that she has had for some time – to start her own business. 

As an intelligent woman, she noticed that her area lacks a stationary store and a photocopier, which brings her to ask for a loan to start her own stationary business. With the loan she will buy supplies for the school year, as well as a photocopier. 

Her dream for her new project is to maintain it, quickly arrive at a place of equilibrium and design her business so that it will allow her to own her own home so that she can live happily with her daughter.

loans.use: start a stationary business, buy supplies for the school year and a photocopier

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase different kinds of cheap fish to sell.

loans.name: Inda Elvira

texts.es: Inda: Es una mujer cordial, que tiene una pequeña pulpería en un anexo de madera que construyó pegado a su vivienda, en la ciudad de  Bilwi; tiene 40 años de edad, casada, tiene tres hijos: 2 adolescentes que estudian su secundaria y un menor de edad de cuatro años.   Antes de solicitar este crédito, trabajó con pequeños créditos como integrante del Grupo Solidario Solteras, pero ahora se ha independizado y está solicitando un préstamo en la modalidad individual para aumentar los productos que oferta en su pequeño negocio. Su sueño es llegar a tener una distribuidora de productos que le genere más ganancia y poder  crear las condiciones que le permitan a ella y a su familia tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Inda is a friendly woman that has a grocery store in a wooden annex that she built onto her house in the city of Bilwi. She is 40 years old, is married, and has 3 children: 2 teenagers who study at secondary school and one young 4 year old child. Before asking for this loan, she worked with small loans as a member of the Solidario Solteras Group, but now she has become independent and is asking for this loan as an individual in order to increase the products that she offers in her small business. Her dream is to eventually become a distributor which would create more earnings and she would be able to create the conditions which would allow her and her family to have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy dairy products, basic staple foods, toilet paper, sparkling water, eggs, instant soups, bread, among other products.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is an 18 year old single man from a village near Nablus city. He lives with his parents and five brothers and sisters in a simple house. His father and brother work as construction workers where they get a low and unstable income. Ahmad is a student in a local collage where he studies Information Technology. He wants to complete his studies and find a job to help his family with part of their expenses.

Ahmad took a USD Murabha loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new laptop for his studies. By taking this loan, Ahmad will be able to do his homework and write reports easily.

Ahmad appears in the photo

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for his studies.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
La Sra. Victoria, la socia pertenece al banco comunal SAN RAFAEL, la socia continua dedicándose al negocio de venta de productos naturales para la salud, la socia agradece el préstamo otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de forma disciplinada, la socia continua vendiendo sus productos naturales a sus clientes que le solicitan cada dia, la socia desea que su negocio prospere, siendo  de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de productos naturales para el colesterol.
texts.en: Victoria belongs to the communal bank San Rafael. This member still runs her business selling natural health products. She is grateful for her previous loan and promises to comply with her payment terms conscientiously. This borrower continues to work selling natural products to the customers that come to her daily. She wants her business to prosper, since it is her means to provide for her family. She is requesting this loan to buy natural products to lower cholesterol.

loans.use: to buy natural products to lower cholesterol.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios is a widow. She lives in Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She became a regular member of PMPC and has actively participated in the various programs and services offered by the Co-op.

She has a small cocoland which gives her a good income every quarter. In order to generate additional earnings for her daily needs, she plans to engage in vending snacks like "pan bisaya" (sweet bread).

Remedios is borrowing money from the Co-op to buy raw ingredients for her food snacks and pay for labour in building her baking and cooking area.

She dreams of nothing more than to live a comfortable life and have adequate income from her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for her food snacks and pay for labour to build a baking and cooking area.

loans.name: Cyprien

texts.en:
Cyprien is a 34-year-old  married man with 2 children who are 1 and 3 years old, they attend school. He has farmed  for 16 years. With the loan from kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers for maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Andrés Camilo

texts.es: Andrés es un emprendedor joven de 25 años de edad,  residente del municipio de Galapa, él se encuentra dedicado a su tienda de víveres desde el año 2012, su idea de negocio surgió cuando salió de su pueblo natal rumbo al municipio de Galapa y decidió vivir en el,  con un capital que su padre le prestó inició el negocio.
